She says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she is no longer able to afford her production expenditure. This has adversely affected production quality. She needs a loan to enable her to scale up production and maintain quality. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of rice, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. 

Christiana is a member of a group called First Kings Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and provide support to one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy raw materials like bags of rice, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Mayte Elena

texts.es:
La señora Mayte decidió ayudar en la economía de su hogar, emprendiendo su propio negocio, tenia varios tipos de negocio en mente pero decidió poner uno que le dejara buenos ingresos y al igual pues darle el mejor servicio a todas las personas de su comunidad: una Papelería, poco a poco le fue surtiendo de todo hasta tener de todo lo que sus clientes le pedían, al igual también los estudiantes le decían que pusiera un cyber café ya que en la escuela les encargan trabajos a computadora y el único cyber que se encuentra en esa colonia esta muy lejos. con las ganancias de la papelería y con el apoyo de su esposo, fue que acondicionando el local y empezaron con el cyber, inicialmente tenían pocas maquinas, ahora con el paso del tiempo ya cuenta con mas maquinas que les da servicio a toda su comunidad y mayormente a los estudiantes.

Ahora ella necesita un préstamo por US $575 que pagara en 6 meses para ampliar y remodelar el local, con tu apoyo ella podrá lograrlo.
texts.en:
Señora Mayte decided to help with the economics of her home by beginning her own business. She had several types of businesses in mind, but she decided on one that would bring her a good income and also would provide the best service to all members of the community: a paperstore. Little by little she was able to grow it until she had all that her clients asked her for. At the same time, the students told her to put in a cyber café so they could do their schoolwork on the computer. The only other cyber café that can be found in the area is very far away. With the profits from the paperstore and with the help of her husband, they air-conditioned the shop and began the cyber café. At first they only had a few machines, now with the passing of time they have more machines that serve all the community, principally the students. Now she needs a loan of US $575 that she would repay in 6 months in order to enlarge and remodel the shop, and with your help she would be able to achieve this.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To enlarge and remodel her business

loans.name: Jose Bernardino

texts.es:
Debido a L. escasez D. trabajo en su pueblo natal el Sr. Bernardino decidió emigrar a L. frontera a trabajar con L. ilusión D. una mejor calidad D. vida. El empezó laborando para una empresa, por algunos años, poco a poco se fue desilusionando debido a que pues no le alcanzaba lo suficiente para solventar los gastos mas indispensables, entonces decidió dedicarse a otra actividad que le dejara pues mejores ingresos, L. cual encontró en una base D. taxis. Hoy en día le ha ido muy bien, ya que el administra su tiempo y pues eso le permite mantener mas tiempo con su familia.

El esta solicitando un préstamo por US $ 375 que pagara en 6 meses para compra D. refacciones y mantenimiento D. L. unidad, el confía que con el apoyo D. Kiva podrá lograrlo.
texts.en:
Given the lack of employment in his native city, Bernardino decided to emigrate to the border to work all int he opes of having a better quality of life.

He had been working for a company for some years but slowly he became disillusioned because he still did not earn enough money to cover his basic needs. So he decided to try something new, something that would proviD. him with better earnings. He found what he was looking for at a taxi cab company.

Until current day it has all gone very well for him, especially because he can manage his own time permitting him to spend more time with his family.

He is requesting a loan in the amount of $375 US that will be repaid in a term of 6 months. With these funds he will purchase spare parts and pay for the labour to repair his cab. He trusts that with the help of Kiva he will succeed.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to repair his taxi cab.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.es:
La señora Angelina S. G. tiene cuarentainueve años y vive en la calle 28 de julio 225 del distrito de Mache de la provincia de Otuzco  del departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió hasta quinto año de primaria y no siguió estudiando porque sus padres tenían una educación muy machista ellos pensaban que deberían recibir educación solo los hombres.
Se casó a los veintidós años con el señor Andrés Flores Gutiérrez y tienen seis hijos, dos de ellos son independientes y dos mujeres y dos hombres todavía son estudiantes.
El primer préstamo que obtuvo de Manuela Ramos fue de 300 soles con lo que compró quesillo, hizo queso y vendió a mayor precio los en cuatro meses.
Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000 soles, el cual será pagado en 4 cuotas, comprará quesillo para vender fuera de la provincia y también utilizará este préstamo para la compra venta de papa  ya que es temporada.
Angelina pertenece al Comedor Popular Sagrado Corazón y también es socia del Banco Comunal Mujeres de Mache del que un tiempo fue presidenta y pertenece ya ocho años.
Su gran sueño es tener un restaurant muy grande que pueda servir bien a propios y visitantes de Mache.
texts.en:
La señora Angelina S. G. tiene cuarentainueve años y vive en la calle 28 de julio 225 del distrito de Mache de la provincia de Otuzco del departamento de La Libertad Perú. Estudió hasta quinto año de primaria y no siguió estudiando porque sus padres tenían una educación muy machista ellos pensaban que deberían recibir educación solo los hombres. Se casó a los veintidós años con el señor Andrés Flores Gutiérrez y tienen seis hijos, dos de ellos son independientes y dos mujeres y dos hombres todavía son estudiantes. El primer préstamo que obtuvo de Manuela Ramos fue de 300 soles con lo que compró quesillo, hizo queso y vendió a mayor precio los en cuatro meses. Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000 soles, el cual será pagado en 4 cuotas, comprará quesillo para vender fuera de la provincia y también utilizará este préstamo para la compra venta de papa ya que es temporada. Angelina pertenece al Comedor Popular Sagrado Corazón y también es socia del Banco Comunal Mujeres de Mache del que un tiempo fue presidenta y pertenece ya ocho años. Su gran sueño es tener un restaurant muy grande que pueda servir bien a propios y visitantes de Mache.

Translated from Spanish by Beatriz Yuste, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fresh curd and potatoes.

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Marcela empezó su pequeño negocio de costurera, lo tuvo por varios años, pero ella veía que no tenía los suficientes ingresos como para ayudar en los gastos familiares, por tal motivo decidió emprender otro tipo de negocio que le dejara mejores ganancias y pues decidió por una tienda de abarrotes. Poco a poco le fue invirtiendo mercancía, ahora ya cuenta con todo lo necesario para satisfacer las necesidades de todos sus clientes, hasta hoy en día le ha dejado buenas ganancias y tiene muchos clientes.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $950 que pagara en 6 meses, para la compra de mercancía, remodelación del local, tiene todas sus esperanzas en el apoyo que brinda Kiva.
texts.en:
Marcela start a small dressmaking business, which she had for several years, but she saw that she did not have enough income to help with the family´s expenses so she decided to start up another type of business which would give her better earnings. That is why she decided to start a grocery store. Little by little she invested in merchandise and now she has everything necessary to meet the needs of all her customers. As of today, the store has given her good earnings and she has lots of customers. She needs a loan for US $950, which she will repay in 6 months, to buy merchandise and remodel the store. All her hopes are on the help that Kiva will offer.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise and remodel her store

loans.name: Yolanda Elsa

texts.es:
La señora Yolanda Elsa M. O. tiene cuarentaicuatro años,  vive en la avenida Campo Bello sin número del distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco, departamento de L a Libertad Perú.
Estudió primaria completa, los padres no nos educaron por falta de Centros educativos, manifiesta.
Se caso de dieciocho años con Hober Salomón Vega y tiene ocho hijos de los cuales cuatro son estudiantes y cuatro tienen trabajos independientes.
La señora compra y vende animales, los compra vivos y los vende en carne, ella manifiesta que gracias al Banco Progresistas, aprendió a ser independiente y a trabajar sola, antes dependía de su esposo, de tal manera que cuando recibió el primer préstamo de 300 soles fue muy cuidadosa en su inversión compró cerdos y de allí se capitalizó y continuo sola, devolvió su préstamo en cuatro meses.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1500 soles, el cual cancelará en 4 cuotas, comprará una vaca y la venderá en carne (al por menor).
Yolanda pertenece comedor popular Corazón de María  y es socia del Banco Comunal Progresistas.
Su gran sueño es que Manuela Ramos crezca mucho más y pueda otorgar préstamos mucho mayores.
texts.en:
Mrs. Yolanda Elsa M. O. is 44 years old. She lives on the Campo Bello Avenue in the Mache district of Otuzco province, in the Peruvian Libertad Department. She completed primary school but her  parents were not able to send her through more schooling because they  did not have adequate access to schools in their neighborhood. She has been married to Hober Salomón since she was 18, and she has 8 children. Four of them are students and the other four have independent jobs. She buys animals and sells their meat, and thanks to Banco Progresistas (a local bank), she learned to be independent and run the business alone instead of depending on her husband as she did before. When she received her first loan of 300 soles, she invested it very carefully. She bought pigs, made a profit, and went on to working alone. She was able to repay the loan in four months. With this loan of 1,500 soles, to be repaid in four installments, she will buy a cow and retail sell its meat. She works for the local soup kitchen Corazón de María and is member of the Banco Comunal Progesistas. Her dream is for Manuela Ramos to keep growing so that the organization can grant her bigger loans.

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle (a cow).

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah K. operates a grocery store in her neighborhood. She started her operation three years ago at Dunkwa-Obuasi, where she lives with her children and husband. She is a 38 year old mother with two children, who are currently in school. She trades in products like rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, and evaporated milk.

With this loan, she wants to buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice and canned foods, and cooking oil to increase her stock of goods. With increased stock and variety, she hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of her children. She would appreciate that assistance very much.

She is a member of the group called neighbors Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To increase and diversify the inventory of her grocery store.

loans.name: Siempre Alegres (Forever Happy) Group

texts.es:
La   asociación “siempre Alegres” ha encontrado oportunidad de negocio en la fruta, de la diversidad de frutas que produce la localidad de Caranavi (provincia  de La Paz). Ellas adquieren productos de los productores,  para luego, en algunos casos venderlos al detalle y en otros casos, convertir  éstos frutos en riquísimos  jugos y zumos naturales que los comercializan en mercados de la ciudad de El Alto. 
La asociación siempre alegres se reúne en el centro focal de Villa Adela, ubicada en la ciudad de El Alto. Felipa Agostopa es la líder del grupo, cuenta que  trabajan con la institución de Pro-Mujer hace mas de siete años y la situación económica de sus hogares a mejorado notablemente desde que reciben el apoyo de dicha institución. Actualmente desean ampliar sus ventas por lo que necesitan mayor capital para la compra de fruta en mayor cantidad.
texts.en:
The "Siempre Alegres" (Forever Happy) association has found its business opportunity in the fruit business, because of the diversity of fruits produced in the Caranavi locality in the Province of La Paz. They buy products from the producers, then, in some cases, sell them retail and in other cases, convert the fruit into very rich natural juices and nectars that are sold in the markets of the city of El Alto. The "Siempre Alegres" association meets in the Villa Adela town center, located in the city of El Alto. Felipa Agostopa is the group leader. They have been working with the Pro-Mujer (Pro-Woman) institution for the last seven years, and the economic situation of the members has noticeably improved since they have received the help of this institution. Currently they want to increase their sales, for which they need increased capital to purchase larger quantities of fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: They need capital to purchase greater quantities of fruit.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria decidió emprender un negocio propio, para poder satisfacer todos los gastos económicos del hogar, y con la ayuda de su esposo lo ha logrado satisfactoriamente. Hoy en día ya son 5 años de dedicarle todo lo mejor a este negocio, para poder obtener buenas ganancias, tener buenos clientes y así poder solventar todos los gastos económicos y la escuela de sus hijos. Gracias a que le ha puesto empeño a su negocio hasta hoy en día le ha dejado buenas ganancias, y tiene muy buenos clientes, gracias al delicioso sazón que ella le pone a todas sus comidas.

Ella esta solicitando un préstamo por US $475 que pagara en 6 meses para la compra de mercancía, compra de vaporeras y compra de tanque de gas, para el negocio, ella confía en el apoyo de Kiva podrá seguir con su negocio
texts.en:
Victoria decided to open her own busines to satisfy the economic needs of her household and with the help of her husband she has succeeded. Today she has dedicated five years to improving her business to get good income, good customers, and to pay for all of the economic costs and school for her children. From her efforts in this business, she has had good earnings and very good customers, thanks to the delicious flavor that she gives to all of her meals. She is applying for a loan of US $475 that will be repaid in 6 months for the purchase of merchandise, steamers and a tank of gas for her business. She relies on the support of Kiva to be able to continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Antonio De Jesús

texts.es: Habitante del Barrio Laureles Norte, del distrito seis de Managua, vive solo en su casa de habitación, donde también trabaja en su pequeño taller de Mecánica y soldadura, lo inició hace 10 años con fondos propios, ya que contaba con la experiencia en estos trabajo y decidió aventurarse poniendo el taller en su casa como alternativa de trabajo.  Le tienen 3 hijos en edad escolar de los cuales apoya a la madre de ellos para su debida alimentación, estudios y salud. En la actualidad solicita este crédito para mejorar el techo de la casa y su mayor deseo es mantener su negocio en vías de crecimiento y poder apoyar a sus hijos para que puedan completar sus estudios
texts.en:
A citizen of Barrio Laureles Norte in the district of Seis de Managua, this person lives alone in his home and also works from his small mechanic and soldering shop. He started 10 years ago this self-funded business having had previous experience in this field of work. He decided to go on his own and set up a workshop in his home as an alternative to working for someone else.

He has 3 school-aged children and he supports their mother with child support, providing for their nutrition, schooling and health.

He is requesting this loan to renovate the roof of his house. His greatest dream is to maintain his business and keep it growing to be able to support his children so that they may finish their studies.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To renovate the roof of his house.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
La señora Teresa  tiene 74 años , nació en Piscopampa caserío de Mache provincia de Otuzco del  departamento de La Libertad Perú,  cursó el primer año de primaria que en su tiempo se llamaba transición, no continuó estudiando más porque murió su madre cuando aun era muy pequeña y   a su padre no le interesaba que las hijas mujeres tengan instrucción.
Se casó a la edad de 18 años  y tiene 7 hijos, de los cuales una hija vive con ella y se ayudan mutuamente la señora Teresa tiene 20 nietos a quienes con su ejemplo les enseña a ser optimistas y a tenerle mucho amor al trabajo.
Anteriormente ella fue costurera, pero ahora se dedica a la compra y venta de material de reciclaje, por ejemplo: plásticos, objetos de fierro, cobre y aluminio, también baterías en desuso.
Recuerda con mucha alegría que el primer préstamo que le brindó  Manuela Ramos fue de 300 soles, hace ya 6 años, lo devolvió en 4 meses, con ese dinero compro cuyes y gallinas y los vendió a los restaurantes de Mache, con las ganancia compró material de reciclaje y así dio inicio a un negocio que actualmente le rinde mayores ganancias. Lo más importante para ella es que cuenta con muy buenos ahorros, manifiesta.
Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000  soles, el cual cancelará en 4 cuotas, piensa comprar baterías y otros materiales de reciclaje por los que le puedan pagar un poco más que por el plástico.
Actualmente sueña con seguir trabajando para seguir respondiendo por ella misma, sin necesidad de depender de nadie.
 Pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres de Trabajo del distrito de Mache.
texts.en:
Teresa is 74 years old and was born in Piscopampa, Peru. She completed the first year of primary school. She did not continue studying because her mother died when she was very young, and it was not important to her father that female children received an education. She married when she was eighteen, and has seven children. One daughter lives with her, and they help each other. Teresa has twenty grandchildren whom she teaches by example to be optimistic and be hard-working. Teresa used to be was a seamstress, but now she works in the buying and selling of recyclable material such as plastic, iron, copper, aluminum and used batteries. She remembers fondly the first loan of 100 USD that she received from Manuela Ramos six years ago. She returned it within four months, and with this money she bought guinea pigs and hens which she sold to restaurants. With her profits, she purchased recyclable materials and thus started a business which now yields greater profits. The most important thing to her is that she can count on her savings. With this loan of 675 USD, which she will pay off in four installments, she plans to buy batteries and other recyclable materials which are worth more than plastic. Now she dreams of continuing working so that she can answer only to herself, without depending on anyone. She is a member of the Working Women’s Communal Bank in the Mache district.

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of batteries, plastics, and other recycled materials.

loans.name: Kwaku

texts.en:
Kwaku D. is 40 years old. He is married with five children who are currently in school. Kwaku D. is a dealer and a producer of rubber bags. He buys his raw materials from importers at wholesale prices and manufactures them into finished goods and distributes them to his customers at retail prices. 

He requests a loan to enable him to procure increased stock of materials such as bundles of rubber of different kinds. He hopes to increase his savings to expand his shop to include foods such as yams, plantains and maize, etc. He would be very grateful for your support. Kwaku has been in this business for the past three years, with a lot of experienced sellers who have wider market shares in his business area. He belongs to the community group called First Kings Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee fone another as social collateral to access loans, and use peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase increased stock of rubber to process them into carrier bags, etc.

loans.name: Segunda Sixtina

texts.es:
La señora Sixtina tiene 47 años y reside en el barrio Alto Trujillo Barrio 2 Lote 35 Manzana A de la ciudad de Trujillo departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Sixtina estudio la primaria completa, pero no siguió mayor estudio porque donde ella vivía no había más que escuela primaria,  para enviarla a otro lugar sus padres se oponían preferían educar a los varones de la casa.
Segunda Sixtina tiene dos hijos uno que es casado y al que lo apoya  con su familia y el otro soltero el que depende enteramente de ella.
Ella en la actualidad compra quesillos y quesos en la sierra y los vende en los mercados de Trujillo y en las casas que los solicitan, por temporadas hace lo mismo con carne de carnero, gallina o cuy.
Ella recuerda con emoción diciendo “no-tenia mucho capital, pero gracias a Dios me contacte con Manuela Ramos y obtuve mi primer préstamo de 300 soles y compre gallinas y cuyes y algo muy importante empecé a ahorrar, antes no lo podía hacer”.
Luego se dio cuenta que el trabajo más cómodo y de mayor ganancia es la venta de queso y quesillo.
Con este préstamo de S/. 800 soles, el cual cancelará en 4 cuotas, comprará queso, quesillo y también higo y azúcar para hacer la miel.
Su gran sueño es tener un negocio grande en un gran mercado.
La señora Segunda Sixtina es una mujer muy luchadora, ella es la fiscal de su Banco Comunal Trabajo y Amor  de Semirustica el Bosque.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sixtina is 47 years old and lives in the  Alto Trujillo neighborhood, (Neighborhood 2, Lot 35, Block A) of the city of Trujilla, in the Libertad department of Peru. She completed primary  school, but did not continue her schooling because there were no schools past primary school in her neighborhood. Her parents had to choose which children to send to secondary schools in other neighborhoods, and preferred to educate the men of the house. Segunda  Sixtina has two children. One is married and Mrs. Sixtina helps him to support his family. The other is single and depends entirely on Mrs. Sixtina. Currently, she buys cheese in the mountains and sells it in the markets of Trujillo and to houses that order them. Seasonally, she also sells mutton, hen or guinea pig meat. She is very touched when she remembers those times, declaring: “I didn’t have much money, but I thank God I contacted Manuela Ramos and obtained my first loan of 300 soles. With this money I bought chickens  and guinea pigs and, more importantly, I learned to economize. I hadn’t been able to do this before.” She later realized that selling cheese was an easier and more lucrative business. With this loan of 800 soles, to be repaid in four installments, she will buy cheese, as well as figs and sugar to make honey. Her dream is to have a big business in an important market. Mrs. Sixtina is a persistent worker who is an auditor for Banco Comunal Trabajo y Amor, in the Semirustica el  Bosque area.

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cheese, figs, and sugar.

loans.name: Waldo

texts.es: El Señor Waldo, trabaja independientemente brindando el servicio de seguridad privada en los colegios de la zona sur de la ciudad de La Paz y en eventos sociales los fines de semana, su esposa lo ayuda en la administración de sus ingresos y en la administración del hogar, tienen una pequeña hija, y viven en la casa de su suegra, es una persona muy responsable, trabajador y cliente antiguo de la institución. El crédito será invertido en la compra de material para un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Waldo works independently providing private security in schools in the area south of the city of La Paz and at social events during the weekends. His wife helps manage the income and the home; they have a young daughter and live in the house of their mother-in-law. He is a very responsible, hardworking and long-term client of the institution. The loan will be invested in the purchase of equipment to provide better service to his clients.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of work equipment

loans.name: Sara Silvia

texts.es:
La señora  Sara Silvia B. D. tiene cincuentaitres años   y vive en la calle San Martín 431 del distrito de Mache de la provincia de Otuzco en el departamento de La Libertad.
Sus padres tuvieron doce hijos de los cuales preferían que estudien los hijos varones, por lo que ella estudió solamente hasta tercer año de primaria lo que ahora equivale a cuarto grado.
Es madre soltera de dos hijos varones y una hija que falleció siendo niña.
Se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado porcino y también a la compra venta de quesillo.
Recuerda con mucho cariño que Manuela Ramos confió en ella y obtuvo un préstamo de 300 soles con los que compró tres ovejas y las vendió en carne.
Con este préstamo de S/ 1,500 soles, el cual cancelará en 4 cuotas, comprará cerdos para venderlos en carne (al por menor).
Sara es una mujer de muchas perspectivas de negocio además piensa que las mujeres siempre deben estar organizadas, por lo que ella pertenece al comedor popular Corazón de María y es una socia muy cumplida de su Banco Comunal Progresistas, ya que en el aprende mucho.
Su gran sueño es viajar a Chili donde se encontrará con uno de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sara Silvia B. D. is 53 years old and lives at 431 San Martín Street, in the Mache District of the Otuzco Province, La Libertad Department. Her parents preferred for, out of their twelve children, the males to go to school. For this reason she only attended school through third grade (now the equivalent of fourth grade.) She is the single mother of two boys and a girl who passed away as a child. She buys and sells pigs as well as cheese. She remembers very fondly that Manuela Ramos trusted her and obtained for her a loan of 300 soles, with which she bought three sheep to sell as meat. With this loan of 1,500 soles, to be paid in four installments, she will buy pigs to sell retail as meat. Sara is a woman with many business prospects. She thinks that women should always be organized, which is why she is a member of the popular Corazón de María dining hall. She is also a very reliable member of her bank, Banco Comunal Progresistas, from which she has already learned a lot. Her greatest dream is to go to Chile to reunite with one of her sons.

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pigs.

loans.name: Rosa Nelly

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Nelly Rodríguez O. tiene 38 años y vive en la calle Soledad sin número en el distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Rosa Nelly estudió hasta sexto grado de primaria, no continuo estudiando debido a que su papá murió y su mamá no tenía los medios económicos para continuar educándola.
Se casó a la edad de veinte años  y tiene dos hijos que dependen solamente de ella ya que se separó de su esposo.
Ella trabaja en la compra venta de ganado porcino y ovino, con el primer préstamo que le otorgó Manuela Ramos y  fue de 300 soles devueltos en  cuatro meses compró conejos y un cerdo.
Con este préstamo de S/. 400 soles, el cual cancelará en 4 cuotas,  ella piensa ampliar su negocio comprando más conejos de mejor raza.
Rosa manifiesta que sueña con tener su propia empresa en Trujillo o en Mache mismo y abastecer de animales a todo el norte del país.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres de Mache.
texts.en:
Rosa Nelly R. O. is thirty-eight-years-old and lives on Soledad street in the Manche district of the Otuzco region in Peru. Rosa Nelly completed her studies through sixth grade. She did not continue her education because her father died and her mother did not have the resources to pay for the rest of her schooling. She married when she turned 20, and she has two children who depend on her, since she had a divorce. She works in the buying and selling of pigs and sheep. With the first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos (300 soles returned in four months), she bought rabbits and a pig. With this loan of 400 soles, which she will pay off in four installments, she wants to expand her business by purchasing more rabbits of a better breed. Rosa has expressed that she dreams of having her own company in Trujillo or Manche and supplying animals to the entire north of the country. She belongs to the Banco Comunal Mujeres de Manche (the Communal Women’s Bank of Manche).

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rabbits

loans.name: Abiba

texts.en:
Abiba A. is a 34-year-old businesswoman. She is married and blessed with two kids. Currently both children attend school. Abiba says combining motherhood and business demands is very challenging. However, the two must be attended to simultaneously.

Abiba has sold bags of maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. for ten years now. She is able to support her household well through this business. She needs the loan to enable her to purchase more stocks of cereals to scale up her sales. She hopes the loan will enable her to double her savings to provide quality education for her kids. Abiba belongs to a group called "Ntoboase" meaning Be Patience Trust Group. The group members assist one another to repay their loan on time.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Paulina María

texts.es:
La señora Paulina María Chávez M., tiene cuarentaicinco años y vive en el caserío Primavera calle Primavera, distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco departamento de La libertad Perú.
Cursó toda la educación primaria, pero ya no pudo continuar sus estudios por falta de medios económicos ya que no había educación secundaria en su distrito.
Se casó a los veinte años con el señor Segundo Ibáñez y tienen tres hijos, uno de ellos ya trabaja y los otros dos son estudiantes.
Tiene un negocio variable, se podría llamar de acuerdo a la estación, pero mayormente se dedica al negocio de productos lácteos, aunque también tiene una pequeña bodega.
Su primer préstamo que hizo a Manuela Ramos fue de 300 soles con los que surtió su bodega, los devolvió en cuatro meses.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000 soles, el cual cancelará en 4 cuotas, comprará trigo y concentrado para sus vacas  con 500 soles y con los otros 500 surtirá su bodega.
Pertenece al Banco Mujeres de Trabajo desde hace cinco años y se siente muy agradecida de Manuela Ramos porque a aprendido a administrar bien su dinero y lo que es más importante a aprendido a ahorrar. 
El sueño más grande que tiene  Paulina es tener una gran tienda, al estilo superM..
texts.en:
Ms. Paulina María Chávez M. is 45 years old and lives in the Primavera country house, located in the Primavera street, in the Mache district of Otuzco, Perú. She finished all of her primary education but was unable to continue her studies for economic reasons, since there are no secondary schools in her district. When she was twenty years old, she married Mr. Segundo Ibáñez. They have three children: one is already working and the others are in school. She has a business that changes according to the season. The majority of the business is dedicated to selling dairy products; however, she also has a small store. Her first loan, which was given by Manuela Ramos, was for 300 soles and she used it to stock up her store. She paid the loan back in four months. She will use half of this 1000 soles loan to buy wheat and concentrate for her cows. With the other half of the loan (to be repaid in four installments) she will stock up her store. She has been a member of Banco Mujeres de Trabajo for the past five years and is grateful to Manuela Ramos because she has learned to manage her money very well; more importantly, she has learned to save her money. Her biggest dream is to have a large store in a supermarket style.

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle food and articles to stock up her store.

loans.name: Ashiatu

texts.en:
Ashiatu M. is 26 years old. She is single and a hardworking young lady. She sells charcoal in her local community. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in most traditional Ghanaian homes. Ashiatu buys her supply of charcoal from the villages and retails them to her customers. She has supported her cousin to finish school with income from her business. She has been in this business for the past nine years. With the loan, she wants to buy more charcoal to serve her customers. She hopes the loan will enable her to save more to support and expand her business. She would be very grateful for that support. 

She belongs to the community group called Ntoboase Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee the repayment of loans for one another.

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Natalia

texts.es: La Señora Natalia es una persona muy sencilla y trabajadora, se dedica a la  venta de leche, para ello tiene dos vacas lecheras, de las cuales obtiene aproximadamente 24 litros de leche al dia. Vive en una casita muy humilde en las afueras de la ciudad con su pequeño hijo, porque su esposo se fue a trabajar a la Argentina y envía remesas mensualmente. Ella cuida de su pequeño hijo con mucho amor. Es una cliente muy puntual y responsable.
texts.en:
Mrs. Natalia is a very simple and hardworking person, dedicated to selling milk, for which she has two milk cows that provide approximately 24 liters of milk a day. She lives in a very humble house in the outskirts of the city with her young son because her husband went to work in Argentina and sends remittances to them monthly. She cares for her small son with great love and she is a punctual and responsible client.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de forraje

loans.name: Petronila

texts.es: Petronila tiene 62 años de edad, habita en el barrio Laureles Norte de la ciudad de Managua, es madre soltera de 2 hijos de 25 y 20 años de edad, quienes son independientes a ella. Ellos apoyan económicamente a su madre en la manutención del hogar. Petronila trabaja lavando y planchando, y también alquila una habitación en su vivienda. Tiene 15 años de dedicarse a esta actividad, y el principal problema encontrado ha sido la facilidad de movimiento de un lugar a otro, ya que su trabajo lo realiza a domicilio, pero ella siempre pone mucho empeño en lograr cubrir los servicios solicitados por sus clientes. Ahora ella dese invertir en su vivienda, el préstamo solicitado es para la construcción de un muro y también para mejorar el servicio higiénico de su vivienda, y así poder optar por una vida más digna para ella.
texts.en:
Petronila is 62 years old, lives in the Laureles Norte neighborhood in the city of Manaqua, and is a single mother of two children, aged 25 and 20 years old, who live independently from her. They support their mother economically in maintaining the home. Petronila works by washing and ironing and also rents a room in her house. She has dedicated herself to this activity for 15 years and the main problem she has encountered has been moving from one place to another, as her work is done at home, but she always gives great effort to providing the services requested by her customers. Now she wants to invest in her home; the requested loan is for the construction of a wall and also to improve the hygenic service of her home and to create a more dignifed life for herself.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construct a wall and improve hygiene

loans.name: Gabriela Graciela

texts.es: La señra Gabriela es de familia humilde. Tiene un hijo pequeño, y junto a su esposo se dedican a la compra y venta de material de recicleje, para ello ya son propietarios de dos tiendas ubicadas en la zona más comercial de la ciudad de La Paz, es cliente atigua de la institución, trabajando con nosotros dos años y medio, por lo que los créditos que ha solicitado han representado una parte fundamental para el desarrollo económico de su pequeño negocio, es por tanto que cuenta con un buen historial creiticio.
texts.en:
Gabriela is from a humble family. She has a young son, and she and her husband are dedicated to the purchase and sale of recyclables. They own two stores located in the most commercial areas of the city of La Paz, Perú. Gabriela is a well-established client of the Emprender institution (Kiva partner), having worked with them for two and a half years. The loans that Gabriela has requested in the past have represented a fundamental part of the economic development of her small business, and she therefore has a good credit history.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Miguel

texts.es:
MIGUEL N. V. is in the process of applying to purchase a home through a Mexican government program called Infonavit.  Infonavit provides working families with a low cost mortgage to purchase a small starter home. Some families’ incomes land them just short of qualifying for the program, however. This Kiva loan allows them to make up the difference with a small supplementary loan and thus qualify to purchase their first home.
EL SEÑOR MIGUEL LABORA PARA UNA EMPRESA EN EL AREA DE MANTENIMIENTO  SU ESPOSA LA SEÑORA GLORIA TRABAJA COMO EMPLEADA DOMESTICA EN  UNA CASA DONDE YA TIENE MUCHOS AÑOS, JUNTOS COMO UN MATRIMONIO UNIDO CON AMOR Y POR LA FUERZA DE SALIR ADELANTE ESTAN SOLICITANDO ESTE PRESTAMO PARA AMPLIAR LA COCINA DE  SU CASA, YA QUE ES MUY PEQUEÑA Y MEDIANTE ESTA REMODELACION ELLOS PODRAN ESTAR MAS COMODOS Y ASI EN UN FUTURO CERCANO PODER TENER UN HOGAR MAS AMPLIO.
texts.en:
MIGUEL N. V. is in the process of applying to purchase a home through a Mexican government program called Infonavit. Infonavit provides working families with a low cost mortgage to purchase a small starter home. Some families' incomes land them just short of qualifying for the program, however. This Kiva loan allows them to make up the difference with a small supplementary loan and thus qualify to purchase their first home. Señor Miguel works for a maintenance business. His wife, Señora Gloria, works as a domestic employee in a home where she has been for many years. Together, in a marriage united by love and by the force of improving their lives, they are asking for this loan in order to enlarge the kitchen of their house. The existing one is extremely small and after this remodelling work, they would be more comfortable and so in the near future they would be able to have a larger home.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To enlarge the kitchen in their home

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: La Sra. Maria Auxiliadora tiene 44 años de edad, con domicilio en el barrio Santa Rosa, tiene tres hijos de 19, 23 y 25 años de edad, uno de ellos ya es independiente y dos están cursando la universida. Es casada, su esposo es contratista en una empresa de Managua. El negocio de Doña Maria es un pequeño restaurante en su casa de habitación. Tiene 44 años de experiencia en este negocio, el cual fue heredado de su mamá. Este pequeño negocio tiene un significado especial ya que es familiar y han hecho mucho esfuerzo para poder sacarlo adelante y de esta manera poder tener ingresos para sustentar a la familia. La solicitud del préstamo es la inverisión en el negocio, será usado en la compra de materia prima para la elaboración de los platos que ofrece a sus clientes. Sus planes a corto plazo son poder invertir en la infraestructura del local, para así poder ofertar un mejor servicio. El mayor anhelo de Maria Auxiliadora es poder darles a sus hijos la educación necesaria para que estos lleguen a convertirse en personas de bien para la sociedad.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Auxiliadora is 44 years of age living in the neighborhood of Santa Rosa. She has three children who are 19, 23, and 25 years of age. One of them is independent and two are studying at university. She is married. Her husband is a contractor for a company in Managua. Maria's business is a small restaurant in her house. She has 44 years of experience in this business, which she inherited from her mother. This small business has special significance since it is a family business and they have put a lot of effort into making it succeed and, in this manner, have income to support the family. The loan will be invested in the business and will be used to purchase ingredients for the dishes that she offers to customers. Her short-term plans are to invest in the restaurant's infrastructure so that she may offer better service. Maria Auxiliardora's greatest wish is to give her children the education that is necessary to become contributing members of society.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make her dishes.

loans.name: Nora Hilaria

texts.es:
Nora es la coordinadora de este grupo, ella inicio su negocio de venta de ropa para poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa comenzó con este negocio hace 5 años vendiendo enfrente de su casa y actualmente vende en mercados rodantes cercanos a su casa.

Blanca inicio su negocio para poder ayudar a su esposo a darles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijas y que no les faltara nada. Inicio hace poco mas de 1 años comenzó como snack vendiendo refrescos, frituras y dulces, actualmente surtió su negocio con más cosas de abarrotes, ya que desea tener su tienda mejor establecida en un futuro.

Nely inicio con su negocio ya que necesitaba una actividad que le permitiera atender a sus hijos y a la vez poder obtener un ingreso extra. Comenzó con este negocio hace 2 años vendiendo para otra persona, pero poco a poco hizo sus clientes por lo que decidió vender independientemente y asi obtener mejores ganancias.

Ellas forman el grupo Kilimanjaro y necesitan $1125 que pagaran en 5 meses para poder comprar mercancía para sus negocios y poder así mantenerlos. Ellas confían que con tu apoyo esto será posible.
texts.en:
Nora is the coordinator of this group. She began her clothing sales business in order to help her husband with the household costs. She started the business 5 years ago by selling in front of her house; she now sells in the markets near her house. Blanca began her business in order to help her husband give their daughters a better quality of life and make sure that they did not lack anything. A little more than 1 year ago, she began selling snack foods such as soft drinks and fried and sweet foods. She currently has her business stocked with more grocery items because she wants to have her store better established in the future. Nely began her business because she needed a job that would allow her to take care of her children and at the same time earn her an extra income. She began this business 2 years ago by selling for another person. However, little by little she got her own clients, which caused her to decide to sell independently, thereby earning her a better income. They constitute the group “Kilimanjaro” and they need $1125.00, which they will pay back in 5 months, to buy merchandise for their businesses and therefore to be able to maintain them. They trust that with your help, this will be possible.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Alma Fabiola

texts.es:
Alma inicio el negocio por el gusto hacia las ventas, los deseos D. superación y D. salir adelante, D. ganar su propio dinero para poder comprar sus cosas y ser una mujer independiente. Comenzó en Junio del 2005 cuando una amiga L. invito a vender ropa, le dijo que era muy buen negocio y acepto, posteriormente compro unos catálogos D. artículos para decorar interiores D. las casa (artesanías), las cuales empezó comprando para su casa, pero a las personas que L. visitaban les gustaban mucho y las empezó a encargar para venderlas y D. ahí a L. fecha le ha ido muy bien.

ElL. necesita un prestamo por US $375 que pagara en 4 meses para comprar variedad D. mercancía para poder ofrecerles mejores opciones a sus clientes y con esto obtener mejores ganancias para invertir nuevamente. Con tu apoyo podra lograrlo.
texts.en:
Alma started her business as she enjoys selling and has a desire for self-improvement, for getting ahead, and for earning her own money to enable her to buy her things and become an independent lady. She started in the year of 2005 when a friend invited her to sell clothes as she told her it was good business; she accepted and later bought catalogues with articles for interior decoration (craftworks) which she started to buy for her own house, but people visiting her liked them so much and she started ordering the items to sell them and from then on she has been doing very well.

Alma needs a loan of $375, to be repaid in 4 months, to purchase a variety of merchandise to offer better options to her clients and thus obtain higher earnings to be invested again. With your support she will succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to improve sales

loans.name: Rosa Isela

texts.es:
Rosa Isela inició el negocio por las ganas de convertirse en una persona independiente, capaz de ganar su propio dinero con esfuerzo y dedicación y no tener que depender siempre de lo que le obsequia su esposo sino poder comprar sus propias cosas y comprarles a sus hijos. Comenzó su negocio hace como 5 años, aproximadamente en Febrero del 2003, gracias a un inquilino que tuvo, al que le rentaba el departamento donde vivía, el era agente de ventas, el la animo a que se dedicar a las ventas por que veía que podría llegar a ser una persona exitosa en este negocio. Lo platico con su esposo y el la apoyó, incluso la financió para que ella pudiera comprar su primer mercancía (ropa) con la incertidumbre de no saber como le iría, pero le fue muy bien y ahora ya tiene muchos clientes

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $375 que pagara en 4 meses para poder surtir ropa y artesanías que le permitan atender mejor las necesidades de sus clientes y así sus ventas puedan aumentar considerablemente. Con tu apoyo esto será posible.
texts.en:
Rosa Isela started the business with the desire to become an independent person capable of earning her own money with effort and dedication, not always having to depend on what her husband can provide but but being able to buy her own things and buy things for their children. She started her business 5 years ago, around February of 2003, thanks to a tenant who was the agent of sales for the apartment they were renting and he inspired her to dedicate herself to sales because he saw that she could become a successful person in this business. She talked with her husband and he supported her decision, even funding it so that she could buy her first merchandise (clothing), uncertain of how it would go, but it went very well and now she has many customers.

She needs a loan of US $ 375 to pay in 4 months to produce clothing and crafts to enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and which could cause her sales to increase significantly. With your support this will be possible.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Produce merchandise

loans.name: Irma Yolanda

texts.es:
Irma el negocio porqué le gusta mucho las ventas y además quería contar con un ingreso extra aparte del que recibo de su esposo, por eso siempre se ha dedicado al comercio y además para mantenerse activa. Comenzó en el negocio de las ventas desde 1981, desde entonces ha vendido tortas, después, ropa de segunda entre amistades y vecinos y como le fue bien, compró algo de joyería y también le fue muy bien y sus ventas han ido aumentando cada vez mas. El crédito anterior de KIVA le ayudó bastante ya que al invertirlo pudo obtener buenas ganancias. En la actualidad, aparte de la venta de joyería también ha comenzado a vender calzado para dama, caballero y niño.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $300 que pagara en 4 meses para adquirir artículos de joyería y de zapatería para tener un mejor surtido para sus clientes y así obtener mejores ganancias. Con tu ayuda esto será posible.
texts.en:
Irma started her own business because she really likes retail and because she wanted to earn an income aside from that of her husband. Because of this reason and because she has always liked to stay active, she has always been involved in business. She got started in sales in 1981. She first sold sandwiches, and then used clothing to her friends and neighbors. Since her business was prosperous, she then purchased some jewelry to sell. She has been successful in this field as well, and her sales have been increasing more and more. The previous loan that she obtained from Kiva helped her a lot because upon investing it, she was able to obtain good profits. Currently, aside from selling jewelry, she has also started to sell footwear for men, women, and children.

She needs a loan of $300.00 USD, which she will repay in 4 months, in order to purchase jewelry and shoes so that she can offer her customers a wider selection of products, thus allowing her to obtain better profits. This will be possible with your help.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise (jewelry and footwear)

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: Francisca Patzàn ha trabajado en la agricultura durante más de 15 años junto con su esposo y sus 5 hijos.  Su principal producto en la agricultura es el suquini, el maíz y el fríjol, por lo que ella necesita el crédito para invertir en la compra de  fertilizantes,  semillas, herbecidas.  Sus metas son poder incrementar su producción ya que  en los meses próximos su producto tiene bastante demanda,  y sus planes son poder mantener bien la siembra y obtener mayores ganancias, ya que esto mismo le da la oportunidad de adquirir otras tierras para cultivar. Francisca también, tiene crianza de pollos y marranos, como una actividad secundaria que le ayuda a mejorar  sus ingresos para su familia, ya que lo que ella desea es poder sacar a sus hijos adelante, dándoles una buena educación.
texts.en:
Francisca Patzán has worked in agriculture for over 15 years with her husband and five children. Their main agricultural product is zucchini, corn and beans, for which she needs credit to invest in the purchase of fertilizers, seeds and herbicides. Her goals are to be able to increase her production because in the coming months her product has enough demand, and they have plans to maintain sowing and obtain higher earnings, which will provide the opportunity to acquire more lands for cultivation. Francisca also raises chickens and pigs, a secondary activity that helps increase the income for her family because she wants to be able to help her children succeed and give them a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds, fertilizer and materials for agriculture

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Im E., 33, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She has a plot of land where she grows rice to earn a living. She makes less than one dollar per day. Actually, her farm is just to support the family. There are many reasons that make her output consistently low. First, her rice field is totally dependent on rain for watering and she sometime does not have enough money to purchase fertilizer to put on her farm. Second, sometimes the crop is damaged by bad weather conditions. 

Her husband is a palm climber who collects palm juice and refines it into sugar. Sugar palm smells good and tastes better than commercial sugar. Her husband has collected palm juice since 1997 and on average he makes US$4 each day. Im E. is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase more tools for her husband to refine palm juice more easily. (The photo shows her husband next to the stove that he uses to refine palm juice to sugar.)

loans.use: To purchase tools to refine palm juice

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Srey S., 29, is married and lives with her five children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She is a vegetable farmer who grows cucumbers, chili peppers, and other crops to earn a living and is able to make US$2 each day. Her husband, Sokha, 34, is a horse-cart driver and also has a business catching fish from the lake in the village. He makes around US$8 in revenue each day. Two of their children are students and the other three are too young to attend school. Srey S. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase more fishing tools for her husband. (Sokha is pictured because his wife was not available.)

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools.

loans.name: Tout

texts.en:
Tout K. is 39 years old and works in agriculture, growing a wide variety of vegetables such as cucumbers, chilies, beans, and mint. She has been farming since 1990, and she is able to earn roughly US $2 each day. Her husband, Chan Touch, is 42 years old. He is a lake fisherman who sells his fish in the village market, earning approximately US $4 each day. The couple and their five children live in Kampong Cham.

Tout would like to take out a loan of US $600 to purchase a sewing machine in order to make additional money tailoring clothing. This increased income will further allow her to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine.

loans.name: Try

texts.en:
Mrs. Try S. is 59 years old and widowed with four children. She sells used goods that she purchases directly from previous owners and resells for a profit. Working hard at her business every day, she earns around US $4 per day.

One of her kids is married; the other children all live with her and each helps to find work to support their expenditures. Her eldest son is a motorcycle taxi drive who works transporting hotel guests. He rents his motorcycle from his uncle, paying US$3.75 per day for use of the bike. But while this payment is regular, his income from taxi driving is not always consistent.

To help increase her family's income, Try is requesting a loan to buy a motorcycle for her son’s taxi business. This way, he won’t have to pay his uncle, and he can increase his profits.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her son's taxi business.

loans.name: Tahira's Group

texts.en:
Tahira baji is the wife of M. I. and lives in Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore is famous for its historical places. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 20 years. She has no children. 

Tahira baji's husband is a daily wage laborer. Tahira baji has a business selling clothes. She has been in this profession for the last 5 years. She successfully repaid her three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members. Shahida baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Rashida baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics for her beauty parlor. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy material (beams) for her shuttering business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Bilquis' Group

texts.en:
Bilquis baji is the wife of M. Munir and lives in a city named Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places. She has been living in this city for the last 20 years. She is the mother of two sons. Bilquis baji's husband is a driver by profession and drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). He has been driving this vehicle for the last 8 years. Bilquis baji is a housewife and sews clothes of her neighbors. She successfully repaid her four loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her husband.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, Zips) to sew school bags to sell. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy clothes to resell. Farhat baji wants a loan to buy electric supplies (wires, tube lights and switch boards) for her electric shop. Fozia baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics for her parlor.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Butum

texts.en: Mrs. Butum M., 29, is a bread seller in her local market. She buys bread from the bread maker and sells them in the market for profit, earning around US$4 per day, while her husband earns around US$3 per day driving motorcycle taxi. The couple lives with four children in Kdol Commune, Battambang Province. To increase her family's income, she needs to add one more business of sugarcane juice, so she would like to request a loan to purchase a machine to make sugarcane juice for sell. The loan will allow her to add business for increasing income.

loans.use: To purchase machine to make sugarcane juice for sell

loans.name: Mrs. Shem Davy Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Shem D. is a group leader of six who all live in the Sdao Kanlaeng Village in Kandal Province. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Suon Sokha, is a car repairer who can make $5 per day. In his business, he now faces a small problem because he does not have enough car equipment to fix his customers' cars. Thus, his wife, Mrs. Shem D., has decided to ask for a loan to buy additional car equipment for her husband's business. 

Mrs. Shem D. is 29 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the youngest child - five years old - is too young to attend school.

loans.use: To buy car repair equipment for her husband's business.

loans.name: Sarwar's Group

texts.en:
Sarwar baji is the widow of M. A. and lives in Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore is famous for its historical places. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 20 years. She is the mother of four children: one son and three daughters. Her son is ten years old but does not go to school. Her daughters make decorative embroidered dresses. 

Sarwar baji runs a canteen in a school and has done this for 6 years. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy material (cloth, beads and patterns) to make more decorative embroidered dresses and to sell them in a big market for a good profit.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members. Maryam baji and Khawar baji each want a loan to repair their auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Rehana baji and Asia baji want loans to buy iron to make chains which are used to tie cattle. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for her decorative embroidery business

loans.name: Sarwar M. Sharif Group

texts.en:
Sarwar baji is the wife of M. Sharif and lives in Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore is famous for its historical places. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 25 years. 

Sarwar baji has a business of making stuffed toys. Sarwar baji's whole family is involved in this business. Sarwar baji didn't learn this skill from anyone; it is her God-given skill. She trained all the members of her family. They have been in this profession for the last 20 years. She is applying for a loan to buy material (cotton, zippers and thread) to make more stuffed toys to sell in a market to earn a good profit.

She is joined in her loan group by three other members. Munaza baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine. Musarat baji wants a loan to buy iron to make chains which are used to tie cattle. Asia baji wants a loan to buy leather to make shoes to sell.

 This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material to make more stuffed toys

loans.name: Ghazala's Group

texts.en:
Ghazala baji is the widow of N. A. and lives in a city named Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places. She has been living in this city for the last 25 years. She is the mother of two sons. Her elder son has a donkey cart which he uses for loading. Her younger son is a daily wage laborer. Ghazala baji has a business of selling milk. She has a buffalo at her house and she gets milk from her and sells it in a milk shop. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another donkey cart for her son.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Shukria baji wants a loan to buy tools to repair air coolers. Razia baji and Nazia baji wants a loan to buy materials (beads, sketches and clothes) for her decorative embroidery business. Kiran baji wants a loan to buy plastic to make plastic frames. Razia baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a donkey cart for loading

loans.name: Jero Made Arsa

texts.id: Walaupun usinya sudah  senja , namun Jero Made Arsa harus terus berusaha karena suaminya,  Ketut Luwer, mengalami stroke sejak satu tahun yang lalu. Jero memelihara banyak babi dibelakang rumahnya. Dengan modal awal Rp.1.000.000,- Jero membeli 1 induk babi, setelah dipelihara selama 6 bulan, induk babi mempunyai anak sebanyak 6 ekor. Jero memberi makan babinya 2x sehari, pada pagi dan sore hari. Selain dedak padi dan dedak gandum, Jero juga memberi daun-daunan seperti, daun pisang, daun talas, batang pisang dan juga ampas tahu. Sekarang induk babi sudah melahirkan lagi  anak sebanyak 9 ekor. Keuntungan yang diperoleh setelah anak babi terjual perekor seharga Rp. 250.000.- Keuntungan ini dipakai untuk membiayai kebutuhan hidupnya karena suaminya sudah tidak mampu lagi bekerja karena sakit. Jero Made Arsa tergabung dalam program Dinari yang jangka waktunya selama 6 bulan dan pengembalian pinjaman pada akhir periode. Harapannya dari pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari Jero akan menambah 1 induk babi lagi dan juga bibit untuk penggemukan sisanya untuk biaya pakan. Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri, dengan bangunan yang cukup permanen, dan anaknya sudah menikah dan tinggal bersama dengan keluarganya.
texts.en:
Even though has been old, Jero Made Warsa should work. Her husband, Ketut Luwer, got heart attacked last year that he can not work anymore. Jero runs a pig breeding business. She raises several pigs behind their house. With Rp 1,000,000 as the initial investment, Jero purchased a pig, and after being taken care for 6 months, the pig produced 6 piglets.Jero feeds her piglets twice a day, early in the morning and in the afternoon. She feeds them with rice and oat hush, and also leaves such as banana leaves, taro leaves, banana stems, and tofu trashes. Now, the pig has produced another 9 piglets. Jero was able to earn Rp 250,000 income for a piglet sold. The income is disbursed to finance their daily needs. Jero Made Warsa has been a member of Dinari for 6 months, and repaid the loan at the end of the period. She hopes that from the loan proposed this time, she will be able to purchase another pig and some piglets to be raised, and the rest will be disbursed to purchase fodder. Jero and his husband live in their own permanent house. Their children have got married and live with their spouses.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana Dyah Kuntari, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase pig, piglets and fodder

loans.name: Ni Putu Ariani

texts.id: Putu Ariani seorang ibu rumah tangga yang punya kegemaran memelihara babi dirumahnya. Dengan modal awal Rp. 2.000.000.-, Ariani membeli 2 ekor babi penggemukan. Setelah dipelihara selama 5 bulan, babi tersebut bisa dijual kembali dengan harga yang lebih tinggi, sedangkan untuk induk babi bisa menghasilkan anak babi antara 8 - 10. Anak babi dipelihara selama 2 bulan dan laku terjual Rp. 200.000,- per ekor. Ariani membeli makan babinya 2x sehari pada pagi dan sore hari. Selain memberi dedak, Ariani  juga memberikan daun-daunan seperti daun pisang, daun talas, batang pisang. Sebelum diberi makan babinya dimandikan dulu dan kandangnya dibersihkan sampai bersih. Keuntungan yang diperoleh sebanyak Rp.80.000,- perekor, setelah dikurangi biaya pakan. Sekarang Ariani sudah memelihara babi penggemukan sebanyak 6 ekor dan 2 induk yang masih produktif. Ariani tergabung dalam kelompok ternak babi yang bekerja sama dengan Yayasan Dinari dalam jangka waktu 6 bulan dan akan melakukan pembayaran diakhir periode. Suaminya, Gusti Made Astawan,  bekerja sebagai pedagang keliling dan tidak banyak yang bisa diharapkan untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarga.  Pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari diharapkan dapat menambah beberapa ekor babi lagi dan sisanya untuk biaya pakan ternaknya.
texts.en:
Putu Ariani is a housewife who likes to raise pigs at her home. With an initial capital of Rp. 2,000,000.-, Ariani bought 2 fattening piglets (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp9,000-10,000.00). After being raised for 5 months, those pigs could be resold for a higher price, while mother pig could produce between 8 - 10 piglets. These piglets would be raised for 2 months and sold for Rp. 200,000/piglets. Ariani feed sher pigs 2x /day morning and evening. Besides rice clippings, Ariani also feed them with leaves, like banana and talas leaves, banana trunks. Before feeding the pigs were bathed, and their stall cleansed. Profit are about Rp.80,000/pig, after deducting feed expenses. Right now Ariani is raising 6 fattening piglets and 2 still productive mother pigs. Ariani is member of a pig farmer group that works together with Dinari foundation, and will make payment at the end of the 6 months. Her husband Gusti Made Astawan works as a travelling salesmen, and could not be expected to pay for all family expenses. Loan obtained from Dinari is hoped to be used to add several more piglets, and the rest to buy feed.

Translated from Indonesian by Gwan Ang, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy piglets and feed (Membeli anak babi dan pakan)

loans.name: Ni Ketut Murni

texts.id: Walaupun sebagai seorang guru TK, Ketut Murni juga masih mempunyai waktu untuk memelihara babi. Ketut Murni tetap berusaha membantu suaminya, Gusti Made Dana,  yang bekerja sebagai seorang Sopir. Ketut Murni memelihara babi dengan modal awal Rp.1.000.000,-.  Ketut Murni membeli 4 bibit babi untuk dipelihara sebagai penggemukan. Ketut Murni memelihara babinya selama 6 bulan, dan laku terjual perekor dari harga Rp.800.000,- menjadi  Rp.1.000.000,- . Keuntungan yang diperoleh perekor sebanyak Rp. 50.000,- setelah dikurangi biaya pakan. Ketut Murni  memberi makan babinya 2x sehari pada pagi dan sore hari. Selain memberi dedak padi dan juga dedak gandum juga diberi makan daun-daunan seperti daun pisang, daun talas dan batang pisang. Sebelum diberi makan babinya dimandikan dahulu sampai bersih dan kandangnya juga dibersihkan. Ketut Murni ikut dalam kelompok ternak babi yang bekerja sama dengan Dinari yang jangka waktunya selama 6 bulan dan akan melakukan pelunasan diakhir periode. Sekarang Ketut Murni sudah mempunyai 2 induk dengan 10 ekor anaknya. Harapannya dengan pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari Ketut Murni akan membangun sebuah kandang yang permanen, sehingga babinya bisa sehat dan bertumbuh dengan baik.
texts.en:
Although a kindergarten teacher, Ketut Murni still has time to raise pigs. Ketut Murni always helps her husband, Gusti Made Dana, who works as a driver. Ketut Murni raises pigs with an initial capital of Rp.1,000,000. (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp9,000-10,000.00). Ketut Murni bought 4 piglets to be fattened. Ketut Murni raise these piglets for 6 months, and could buy for Rp.800,000 and sell for Rp.1,000,000/pig. Profit is Rp. 50,000/pig after decucting feed cost. Ketut Murni feed her pigs 2x/day mornings and evenings. Besides feeding rice and wheat clippings, she also fed banana, talas leaves, and banana trunks. Before feeding she bathe the pigs until clean, and also clean the stall. Ketut Murni is member of a pig farmer group that works together with Dinari foundation, and will make payment at the end of the 6 months. Right now Ketut Murni already has 2 mother pigs and their 10 piglets. Her hope is from Dinari's loan, Ketut Murni could build a more permanent pig stall, so that her pigs would be healthier, and grow well.

Translated from Indonesian by Gwan Ang, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a more permanent pig stall (Membuat kandang babi yang lebih permanen)

loans.name: Sambat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambat K., 24, and her husband, Mr. Than Noy, 21, are both rice farmers. They have one young child, and they live in the Pteah Rong Commune in the Pursat Province. Together, they earn about 8,000 Riel (US $2) per day.

As farming is their main source of income, it’s important that Sambat takes good care of their rice crops. Without fertilizer, their farm land becomes infertile, but fertilizer is quite expensive. Sambat first heard about the potential of a Kiva loan through HKL’s promotion, and she would like to request a loan of 800,000 Riel (US $200) to buy fertilizer for her rice crops. The remainder of her loan will be used to buy rice seeds.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her rice crops and purchase more rice seeds.

loans.name: Jane Lucia

texts.es:
Jane tiene 36 años. Desde hace algún tiempo se dedica a la venta de tortas y empanadas, a la vez, ella trabaja  ayudando a sus vecinas haciendo trabajos diversos, lo cual le permite tener algunos ingresos extras.

Jane tiene dos hijos, que actualmente asisten al colegio. Algunas veces por el trabajo, Jane tiene que dejar solos en casa a sus pequeños hijos, y eso le preocupa mucho.

Los créditos que Jane ha recibido anteriormente le han ayudado a invertir en los insumos para la preparación de sus tortas y empandas.

A ella le gustaría tener un negocio de repostería en su casa, para así poder estar más cerca de sus hijos y no descuidarlos.
texts.en:
Jane is 36 years old. For some time now she has sold empanadas and baked goods, which, along with various jobs she does for her neighbors, allow her to earn additional income. Jane has two children, both of whom are in elementary school. At times Jane is forced to leave her two children at home alone due to work. This worries Jane greatly. Previous loans which Jane has received were used to purchase supplies to use in the preparation of her empanadas and other baked goods. Jane dreams of having her own bakery in her own home. This would allow the to be closer to her children and never have to leave them alone.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of supplies for the preparation of bakery goods.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Noy Leang Y Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This Village Bank consists of 16 members and is located in the Traeuy Troeng Village of Kandal Province. They plan to use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Noy L. Y is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a cow breeder who raises two cows. Her husband, Mr. Toun Sophorn, is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. With the revenue, he can purchase veR. little because he owns a small piece of land. Mrs. Noy L. Y is 32 years old and the mother of five children, four of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study. Although Mrs. Noy L. Y's family members have different businesses, they still cannot afford to take care of their family veR. well. Therefore, Mrs. Noy L. Y has decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets to start a pig-breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Two members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy piglets to start a pig breeding business.

loans.name: Mrs. Un Hay Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Un H. is the village bank president. She is 33 years old, and the mother of three children; two of whom are attending the local school. Her youngest child is only three years old, and thus too young to study or work. The village bank, which is comprised of seventeen members, is located in Tuol Sralau Village in Kampong Chang Province.

Mrs. Un H. is also a farmer in the local village, where she owns a 1.5 hectare rice field. Presently, however, she faces a small problem in her field, as she needs fertilizer, which is quite expensive. Her husband, Mr. Choem Hoeun, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make US $2.5 per day. He also helps his wife in the field, but their income is small for their family. As a result, Un is asking for a loan to purchase fertilizers in order to produce better crops.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Eight members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product, because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. This type of loan allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term, but most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva loans.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers in order to produce better crops.

loans.name: Thi Lan's Group

texts.vi:
chị C. thị Lan năm nay 49 tuổi Ms 13030046 chị là một phụ nữ rất năng động, hàng ngày ngoài việc chăn nuôi và làm ruộng , chị còn làm đồ thờ cúng. Chồng chị và các con chị hàng ngày đều phụ giúp chị sản xuất và kinh doanh. Khi được nghe cán bộ của Bình Minh CDC tuyên truyền về hình thức vay vốn trả dần chị đã đăng ký tham gia, chị rất thích hình thức vay trả này, vì nó phù hợp với việc thu nhập của gia đình chị, đồng thời giúp chị tích kiệm và có kế hoạch cho tương lai. Hiện tại thu nhập của gia đình chị từ 200.000 VND đến 250.000 VND/ ngày. C. kỳ này chị đăng ký vay ở mức 3.186.000 VND để đầu tư vào mua tre, nứa nhằm mở rộng sản xuất và buôn bán nhỏ. Các thành viên trong nhóm chị :

  • chị Nguyễn thị Thìn Ms 13030043 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để mua gạo sản xuất mỳ bán .
  • chị C. thị Xuân Ms 13030044 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để mua tre, nứa về đan.
  • chị N. thị Thân Ms 13030045 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để mua thức ăn cho gà, vịt.
  • chị Đặng thị Toản Ms 13030047 vay mức 2.242.000 VND để sản xuất đồ tre, nứa bán
  • chị Đặng thị Xuân Ms 13030048 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để mua cám lợn và sản xuất mỳ bán
texts.en:
Mrs C. thị Lan is 49 years old. She is an active woman. Everyday she works in the rice field, tends the pigs and makes religious craft. Her husband and children contribute to increase the family income. When she heard about SEDA program, she signed up. She likes this program because she can make weekly payment and it enables her to save. Today, her family income is 200.000 - 250.000 VND a day. This time she is requesting a bigger loan: 3.186.000 VND to buy bamboo for her craft. Other members in her group are :
  • Mrs Nguyễn thị Thìn, seeking 3.186.000 VND to buy rice to produce noodle .
  • Mrs C. thị Xuân Ms, seeking 3.186.000 VND to buy bamboo to make craft.
  • Mrs N. thị Thân Ms, seeking 3.186.000 VND to buy feed for her chickens and ducks
  • Mrs Đặng thị Toản, seeking 242.000 VND. She makes craft from bamboo
  • Mrs Đặng thị Xuân, seeking 3.186.000 VND to buy feed for her pigs.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: make religious craft, raises poultry

loans.name: Thi Hông Thăm's Group

texts.vi:
chị Nguyễn thị hồng Thắm năm nay 23 tuổi Ms 13010027 chị là một phụ nữ rất chịu khó và năng động. Chị đã tham gia vay vốn của Bình Minh CDC qua một C. kỳ và hoàn trả rất tốt. Đồng thời giúp gia đình chị mở rộng kinh doanh đem lại thu nhập ổn định cho gia đình. Hàng ngày ngoài việc chăm sóc con nhỏ, chị còn buôn bán quần áo và bán tại chợ, còn chồng chị làm nghề lái xe, chuyên vận chuyển hoa quả và hàng hoá nên mức thu nhập của gia đình chị khá ổn định từ 150.000 VND đến 200.000 VND/ ngày. C. kỳ này chị tiếp tục đăng ký tham gia vay mức 4.704.000 VND để mua thêm quần, áo về bán. Các thành viên trong nhóm chị như sau :

  • chị C. thị Liên Ms 13010032 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để kinh doanh hàng hoa quả
  • chị Lê thị Thuý Ms 13010024 vay mức 4.256.000 VND để đi chợ và mua tre nứa về đan để bán
  • chị Nguyễn thị Oanh Ms 13010050 vay mức 2.242.000 VND để mua máy may ( trả trong 25 tuần )
  • chị Nguyễn thị Sáu Ms 13010029 vay mức 2.016.000 VND để chăn nuôi và mua tre nứa về đan để bán
  • chị Nguyễn thị Xuân Ms 13010051 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để chăn nuôi và đi chợ bán hàng bánh kẹo ( trả trong 25 tuần )
texts.en:
Mrs Nguyễn thị hồng Thắm is 23 years old. She is a hard working woman. She has already her first loan with SEDA. It helped her family to have a stable income.
