Everyday she sells clothes at the market . She also takes care of her young child. Her husband is a truck driver, delivering merchandise. Her family income is stable: 150.000 - 200.000 VND a day. This round she is requesting a loan of 4.704.000 VND to buy clothes to sell. Other members in her group are:
  • Mrs C. thị Liên, seeking 4.256.000 VND. She sells fruits and flowers
  • Mrs Lê thị Thuý, seeking 4.256.000 VND to buy bamboo to make baskets
  • Mrs Nguyễn thị Oanh, seeking 2.242.000 VND to buy a sewing machine
  • Mrs Nguyễn thị Sáu, seeking 2.016.000 VND. She makes bamboo baskets and raises poultry
  • Mrs Nguyễn thị Xuân, seeking 3.186.000 VND. She sells basic goods and candies

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: vốn buôn bán

loans.name: Haydee

texts.es:
Haydee tiene 52 años. Ella se dedica actualmente al pequeño negocio que tiene en la puerta de su casa, donde vende diversos productos, como golosinas, jugos y tortas.

Haydee, con el pequeño negocio que tiene, solventa los gastos de su hija, que estudia en un instituto superior.

Con el ultimo crédito que Haydee recibió compro materiales para aprender a hacer carteras y monederos de manera artesanal. Ella cuenta que le gustaría empezar un negocio en este rubro, pero también le gustaría invertir en su negocio de venta de golosinas.
texts.en:
Haydee is 52 years of age. She currently runs a small business, selling various products like sweets, juice, and cakes on her front porch. With her small business, Haydee covers the expenses of her daughter, who is currently studying in an institution of higher learning. With the last loan that she received, Haydee bought materials to learn how to make handmade wallets and coin purses. She states that she would like to start a business in this branch, but she would also like to invest in her snack business.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to produce handmade wallets and coin purses

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Oin Ly Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people, all of whom live in Cheung Voat Village in Kampong Cham Province, have formed a village bank. Mrs. Oin L. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who cultivates her crops twice a year. In the rainy season, Mrs. Oin L. grows rice, and in the dR. season she grows vegetables. PresentL., however, she faces a small problem in her field, as she needs fertilizer, which is quite expensive. To deal with this problem, Mrs. Oin L. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers in order to make her fields more productive. Her husband, Mr. Kol Min, helps his wife in their rice plantation. They have two children, both of whom are construction workers who contribute to their famiL.'s small income.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainL. end-of-term loans. Twelve members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthL. payment loans. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. This type of loan allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able to do so. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term, but most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of onL. 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva loans.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers in order to make fields more productive.

loans.name: Charly Smith

texts.es:
Charly  tiene 21 años. Hace dos  años empezó su negocio de zapatería, al cual le dedica la mayor parte de su tiempo.
El empeño que pone en su trabajo se lo debe al nacimiento de su hija, la cual apenas tiene dos meses de nacida.

El último crédito que recibo Charly le sirvió para comprar materiales para su zapatería, como suelas y pegamento. 
Además, él cuenta que necesita hacer crecer su negocio, ya que con los ingresos que tiene muchas veces no le alcanza para mantener a su hija recién nacida.
texts.en:
Charly is 21 years old. Two years ago, he opened his own shoe repair shop, to which he devotes most of his time. All the effort that he puts in his work is due to the birth of his daughter, who is only two months old. The last loan that Charly received was used to purchase materials, such as soles and glue, for his shoe repair shop. Furthermore, he needs to make his business grow because often times he does not earn enough income to support his newborn daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in materials for shoe repair shop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Kean Ol Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people, all of whom live in Cheung Voat Village in Kampong Cham Province, have formed a village bank. Mrs. Kean O. is the village bank president. She is a 40-year-old widow with four children: two of whom are employed in a garment factory, while the remaining two attend the local schoO.. Kean is a cow breeder, but she also owns one pig. Although her family works hard in different businesses, they still live in poor conditions. As such, Mrs. Kean O. is requesting a loan to buy piglets to start a new pig breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and live in better conditions with this new loan.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product, because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. This type of loan allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term; but most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a 0% default rate on Kiva loans.

loans.use: To buy piglets to start a new pig breeding business.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is a 43 year old entrepreneur and mother of seven children, who are all going to school. She lives in Kisumu, Kenya and began her current business selling second-hand and new clothes in 1996. She specializes in women's clothing, like skirts and dresses, as well as bed sheets. She periodically travels to Kampala in Uganda, where she is able to purchase a good variety at wholesale prices. The prime location of her business on a busy street, her many years of experience, and her friendly interaction with customers has enabled her to establish a good client base.

With this loan of $600, Pamela plans to expand her business by buying stock of new clothes.

loans.use: To buy stock of new clothes.

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Sareth Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, located in Kong Chey Village, consists of eighteen people who plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sok S. has been selected by the members as the village bank president. She is 47 years old, and the mother of two children who attend the local school. She is a farmer who owns a one hectare rice field. She faces a small problem in her plantation, because her field is now infertile. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Sok S. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers in order to make her field and crops more productive. Her husband, Mr. Taing Than, is a teacher who earns roughly $50 per month, but this is not enough income to support their family.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product, because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. This type of loan allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term; but most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a 0% default rate on Kiva loans.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers in order to make her rice field and crops more productive.

loans.name: Chanthea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthea K., 38, is a farmer who grows rice. Her husband, Mr. Doeun Cheam, is a policeman who has a small monthly salary. They have three children, all of whom are in school. The family's living condition is not very good because of the increasing prices of food and other goods. Chanthea and Doeun both work hard everyday to provide for their family, but their income is insufficient for their daily expenses.

To increase their income, Chanthea needs a loan of 1,000,000 Riel ($250 USD) to purchase piglets to breed and to buy fertilizer for her rice crop. The family lives in Ptas Rong Commune, Pursat Province, Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and fertilizer.

loans.name: Mrs. Phon Ry Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, located in Damank Ampil Village in Kampong Cham Province, consists of fourteen people who plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Phon R. is the village bank president. She is a 50-year-old mother of two children: one of whom is a construction worker, while the youngest is enrolled in the local school. She is also a farmer who owns a two hectare field. She faces a small problem in her plantation, because she does not have enough money to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow her field. Thus, she is requesting a loan in order to pay for this service. With the remainder of the loan, she will buy fertilizers and pesticides to support her crops and make them more productive. Her husband, Mr. Leng Luy, helps his wife on the plantation. The five men shown in the picture above are representing their wives, who are also requesting loans, but who were busy at work and unable to have their photo taken.

This is a village bank loan consisting entirely of end-of-term loans. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product, because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. This type of loan allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term; but most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a 0% default rate on Kiva loans.

loans.use: To hire a laborer with two oxen to plow her field in order to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is a 30-year old married mother of four children. She lives with her husband and children in Kisumu Kenya. Since 2002, she has sold essentials items such as bread, rice, flour, sugar, cooking oil, and so forth. Her hard work, perseverance, good reputation, and many years in business coupled with a well-established clientele base ensure that her business will continue to grow. She has applied for a loan of US $500. She plans to use part of the loan to purchase additional stock in bulk and to save part of it to use in case of unforeseen circumstances.

loans.use: Purchase additional stock of essential items in bulk.

loans.name: Nazakat

texts.en:
Nazakat (her daughter is pictured)  was born in 1965. She is married, has two children, and lives in Khirdalan town in Azerbijan. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory in the Djabrayil region of Azebaijan. She started this beauty salon business eight years ago. 
Now she is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy the necessary things for improving her business and providing her clients with the best service.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her beauty salon

loans.name: Zar Mohammad

texts.en:
Zar M. is 52 years old; he is married, with 5 children. He has a clothing sales shop in a good area of Kabul, where he has worked for more than 5 years. He loves to maintain his business to help his family.

Now Zar M. is requesting an individual loan of 50,000 Afghans ($1075), for the term of 18 months, to import more Indian and Afghan clothes to sell in his shop.  This will allow him to attract more clients and make a good monthly income to help his family and create a bright future.

He is happy with the loan process in Afghanistan. He would like to thank lenders and Kiva for the opportunity to be more successful in his business.

loans.use: To import more Indian and Afghan clothes

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en: Nizami has been selling building materials for five years. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Kalbadjar region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. He is married, has two children, and now lives in the Absheron region.  Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy spare parts for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy the spare parts

loans.name: Thi Tam's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Tâm, sinh năm 1957 (Ms 23010147), mức vay: 4.452.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Hiện nay gia đình cô có 1000 con gà đẻ trứng. Song song với nuôi gà, gia đình cô còn có nghề làm đậu phụ cung cấp cho người dân trong làng, đồng thời cô nuôi một con bò và lợn. Trứng gà đẻ và đậu phụ làm ra chính là nguồn thu chủ yếu của gia đình cô đem lại thu nhập bình quân theo ngày khoảng 150.000 vnđ đến 200.000 vnđ. D. đó cô có thể nuôi 3 con ăn học và trả vốn hàng tuần. Cùng vay vốn với cô còn có các thành viên:
Trần Thị Liên, sinh năm 1959 (Ms 23010143), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ.
Bùi Thị Huệ, sinh năm 1956 (Ms 23010144), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi(mua cá giống về thả ao)
Nguyễn Thị Sáng, sinh năm 1978(Ms 23010145), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư mua bò.
Ngô Thị Lừng, sinh năm 1962(Ms 23010151), mức vay: 2.436.000 vnđ để mở rộng cửa hàng bán đồ ăn sẵn(Thịt chin, giò, trả)
Đỗ Thị Ái Ân, sinh năm 1983 (Ms 23010148), mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ bán hàng khô(Gia vị, măng,...)
texts.en:
Mrs. N. Thi Tam (ID Number 23010147), born in 1957, would like to borrow 4,452,000VND to invest in raising chickens. Currently, her family has 1000 chickens giving eggs everyday. Besides that, her family also makes tofu to sell to the villagers, as well as rears pigs and a cow.Chicken eggs and the tofu sold have become the main source of income for her family, bringing about a daily income of 150,000VND to 200,000VND (about 9USD to 12USD). Thus, Mrs. Tam is able to send her three children to school and repay the loan weekly. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. T. Thi Lien (ID Number 23010143), born in 1959, borrows 4,028,000VND to invest in her business.
  • Mrs. B. Thi Hue (UD Number 23010144), born in 1956 , borrows 4,028,000VND to invest in raising livestock (purchasing breeding fish to raise in pond)
  • Mrs. N. Thi Sang (ID Number 23010145), born in 1978, borrows 4,028,000VND to purchase cows.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Lung (ID Number 23010151), born in 1962, borrows 2,436,000VND to expand her food store (selling cooked meat, pork-pie, grilled chopped meat, etc.)
  • Mrs. Đo Thi Ai An (ID Number 23010148), born in 1983, borrows 3,604,000VND to sell dried food stuff (eg. spices, bamboo shoots etc.)
  • The total amount requested is 1,375USD.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising livestock

loans.name: Said

texts.en:
Said Q. is a hard-working man who graduated from class twelve last year, and started a small business with a lot of dreams.  Q. is 23 and single. He and his family have been living in the Behsood district for about 6 years. Before that they were living in Pakistan as refugees.

Said Q. has two brothers and a sister, who are studying at a public school.  His father had a small retail shop in the Behsood bazaar, but recently he has been faced with some serious illnesses, so doctors recommended that he rest at home for a few months. This was the reason that Q. accepted all responsibilities and started working in his father's shop.

His shop is near a public school, and he sells different goods, such as milk, shampoo, pens, and juice.  His daily income is just 150 Afghanis (US $3), not enough to support his his family. So Said Q. has decided to expand his business. He thinks that if he purchases some stationery to sell, he will attract more customers and thus solve his financial problems. Therefore, he has requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghanis (US $1075) for 12 months. He also has 25,000 Afghanis of his own capital.

Q. hopes to stand on his own feet as soon as possible, and then start his remaining education in his spare time.  He also wants to help his father get well, and he doesn't want his siblings to stop their studying for any reason. Finally he expresses his appreciation to the lenders who assist poor people through a hard situation.

loans.use: To purchase some stationery to sell in his shop

loans.name: Eng

texts.en:
Eng S. is 31 years old. She is married and lives with five children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1995, she has been growing rice to make a living, and she earns roughly US $1.5 each day. She explains that planting rice is difficult because of poor weather conditions. She works very hard, but isn’t able to make a lot of money to support her family members, as she sometimes faces problems with availability of enough water for her rice plantation. She explained to a loan officer that even during the rainy season there is sometimes not enough water for her rice plants.

Inflation is another one of the main obstacles that all farmers face. With skyrocketing prices of agricultural products, such as fertilizer and rice seeds, many farmers cannot afford the tools of their trade, and it becomes harder to make a profit.

Eng’s husband, Seng Nat, is a fisherman. He has been catching fish since before they were married, and he earns about US $3.5 each day. He learned to fish by following his neighbors down to the river every day and learning the skill from them. This is how he acquired the knowledge to be a successful fisherman, and he then started his own business.

Mrs. Eng S. is requesting a loan from Kiva via the local partner CREDIT, to purchase more fishing tools for her husband. (Her husband, Seng, is pictured above in front of their home.)

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools.

loans.name: Mr. Eng Am's Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mr. Eng A. is 45 years old and has four children, one of whom helps Mr. Eng A.'s plantation and another one who is employed in a garment factory. The remaining two are attend the local school. Seventeen people in Chrey Bet Meas Village in Kampong ChA. Province formed a village bank loan and Mr. Eng A. is the village bank president. He is a construction worker who does not earn enough money to support his family. Aside from working in construction, he is a farmer who owns two hectares of land in which he cultivates rice. However, his plantation has become infertile and is unable to produce any more food. To solve this problem, Mr. Eng A. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to enrich his plantation. He would also use the loan to purchase pesticides to kill crop destroying insects. His wife, Mrs. Kong Nuon, is a Khmer cake seller who earns $2.50 per day, which is not enough to support her family. Together, they would like to be able to provide a quality education and future for their children.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Hean

texts.en: Hean S., 27, is a rice farmer who lives with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. On average, she makes around $2.5 USD each day. Her husband, Thou Sinat, 29, is a taxi driver (Phnom Penh- Siem Reap) and is able to make $4 USD each day. He said he used to make more profit, but the high price of gas makes him earn less. Hean is asking for a loan of $1000 USD to sell grocery products. She said her husband will purchase groceries in bulk and then distribute them to small buyers in Siem Reap province and Phnom Penh city. (Thou is pictured in Hean's rice field.)

loans.use: To buy groceries.

loans.name: Nasimjon

texts.en:
N. Nasimjon is 24 years old. In spite of his young age he is working and supporting his parents. He is an expert in DVD recording services. For more than eight years he has provided audio editing of videotape and DVD recordings of the family events of his clients. Nasimjon tries to use modern up-to-date technologies in his work so that he can satisfy the demands and requirements of the customers. 

Nasimjon dreams of getting a higher education. But unfortunately that is impossible as his parents currently are not working. Nasimjon has to work hard because he is the only breadwinner in his family. 

Now he is planning to purchase a new modern computer in order to improve the quality of his work and to expand the business. For this purpose Nasimjon requests 3400 Somoni (US $1000) for the term of 12 months. This is Nasimjon's first loan.  He thanks everyone for their support and promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing a new modern computer in order to improve the quality of his work.

loans.name: Thi Huong's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Hương, sinh năm 1965 (Ms 23010111), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.876.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi bò. Chị đang sống cùng chồng vá hai con gái tại thôn Lực Canh Xuân Canh Đông Anh Hà Nội. Hàng ngày, ngoài công việc đồng áng, chăn nuôi, chị vẫn đi làm thuê như phu hồ, nhặt quă mơ để làm ô mai,...Chồng chị là thợ xây, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 2.500.000 vnđ /tháng. Ở thôn chị là một cán bộ phụ nữ năng động, nhiệt tình với các hoạt động phong trào nên trong làng ai cũng biết và yêu quý chị. Cùng tham gia vay vốn với chị còn có:
Nguyễn Thị Chi, sinh năm 1977 (Ms 23010107), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.452.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ bán rau, gà.
Vũ Thị Luật, sinh năm 1977 (Ms 23010108), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.452.000 vnđ để đầu tư nuôi gà(mua thêm 200 con gà giống)
Lê Thị Chín, sinh năm 1978 (Ms 23010109), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.452.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng nay mặc.
Nguyễn Thị Hương, sinh năm 1957 (Ms 23010110), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.452.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi.(lợn, bò, gà)
Nguyễn Thị Thu, sinh năm 1970 (Ms 23010112), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.452.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi.
Nguyễn Thành, sinh năm 1973 (Ms 23010011), tham gia vay vốn mức: 1.060.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ hoa quả.
texts.en:
Mrs. N. Thi Huong (ID Number 23010111), born in 1965, would like to borrow 4,876,000VND to invest in rearing cows. She lives with her husband and her two daughters at Luc Canh village, Xuan Canh town, Đong Anh, Ha Noi. Everyday, besides farming and raising livestock, mrs. Huong also works as a hired worker in construction sites, and picks up apricots to make sugared dry apricots for saL.. Her husband is a construction worker. Her family's average monthly income is 2,500,000VND (about 152USD). Mrs. Huong is an active and enthusiastic officer of her village's woman association, so the villagers all know and like her. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. N. Thi Chi (ID Number 23010107), born in 1977, borrows 4,452,000VND to sell vegetabL. and chicken.
  • Mrs. V. Thi Luat (ID Number 23010108), born in 1977, borrows 4,452,000VND to invest in raising chicken (purhchasing 200 breeding chickens).
  • Mrs. L. Thi Chin (ID Number 23010109), born in 1978, borrows 4,452,000VND to invest in her tailoring shop.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Huong (ID Number 23010110), born in 1957, borrows 4,452,000VND to raise livestock (pigs, chickens, cows).
  • Mrs. N. Thi Thu (ID Nubmer 23010112), born in 1970, borrows 4,452,000VND to raise livestock.
  • Mrs. N. Thanh (ID Number 23010011), born in 1973, borrows 1,060,000VND to buy and sell fruits.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising livestock

loans.name: Mr. Yuy Sarin Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mr. Yuy S. is the village bank president of fourteen people who all live in Trapeang Sangke Village in Kampong Cham Province. All of these members will make use of the loan for different purposes. For instance, Mr. S. is a pig breeder and is currently raising four pigs. As his pigs grow, he needs more and more money to buy food for them and would use his loan for this food. His wife, Mrs. Roeurn Ra is a vegetable farmer who owns one hector to grow potatoes.  Mr. S. is 46 years old and a father of two, one of which attends the local school. This loan would allow Mr. S., his family, and his village to get what they desperately need in order to maintain the wellness of their community.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy pig food to feed her pigs

loans.name: Waisdin

texts.en:
Waisdin is married and lives in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan.  He has a retail shop with two other workers, where he has worked for more than 8 years. Before opening this retail shop he was in Iran with his family, where he worked in a shop.  When he came to Kabul he opened his own retail shop.

Now he wants to take out an individual loan to complete his retail stock and further his business.  He wants to succeed and become strong in his business to support his family.  He is happy with this loan process. He would like to thank those who help poor people in his country, and he would like to continue this partnership.

loans.use: To complete his retail stock

loans.name: Mrs. Sun Kan Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank loA. is compromised of nineteen members all of whom live in the Tang Thlaeng Village in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. Mrs. S. K. was selected by the members of the Village Bank to become the President. She is a farmer who owns 1.5 hectare rice fields. But, she does not have enough money to purchase rice seeds so she is asking for a loA. so that she cA. continue cultivating rice. With the remainder of her money, Mrs. S. K. would purchase fertilizer to help the production of her crop. Her husband, Mr. Suk Sam, is a construction worker who makes around $1.50 per day. With this small income, it is very hard to meet the needs for their family’s expenses. Mrs. S. K. is 40 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one, age 3, is still too young to work or study. Mrs. Yoen S. represents her husband who is not in the picture but is applying for a loA..

This is a village bank loA. consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Eleven members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loA. until the very end of the loA. term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loA. term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds to cultivate rice and she would use the rest of the loan to purchase fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Thu Ha's Group

texts.vi:
Lê Thu Hà, sinh năm 1973 (Ms 10060007). Chị tham gia vay vốn mức: 4.876.000 vnđ để mở rộng kinh doanh cửa hàng bán mỹ phẩm. Chồng chị là lái xe, hai con chị còn nhỏ. Thu nhập bình quân cùa gia đình chị khoảng 4.000.000 vnđ / tháng. Chị vốn là người có ý thức tốt và có trách nhiệm nên trong nhóm ai cũng tin tưởng chị. Vợ chồn chị rất thích vốn vay trả dần và mong muốn tham gia vay vốn lâu dài tại tài chính vimô Binh Minh. Trong nhóm vay của chị còn có:
Nguyễn Thị Hạnh, sinh năm 1978 (Ms 10060017), tham gia vay mức vốn; 2.204.000 vnđ để đi chợ.
Lưu Thị Huyền, sinh năm 1982 (Ms 10060007), tham gia vay vốn mức: 4.452.000 vnđ để đầu tư mở rộng hiệu may đo.
Nguyễn Thị Thúy Huyền, sinh năm 1982 ( Ms 10060008), tham gia vay vốn mức: 4.028.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi lợn, gà.
Trần Thị Phượng, sinh năm 1986 (Ms 10060009), tham gia vay mức vốn: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng bán đồ ăn sang(xôi, phở, bánh mì)
texts.en:
Mrs. L. Thu Ha (Ms 10060007), born in 1973, would like to borrow 4,876,000VND to expand her cosmetic store. Her husband is a driver, and her children are still small. Her family's average monthly income is 4,000,000VND (about 242USD). Mrs. Ha is a righteous and responsibL. person so all the group members trust in her. Her husband and she really like the installment basis of payment and thus, would like to continue borrowing through the SEDA Fund. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. N. Thi Hanh (ID Number 10060017), born in 1978, borrows 2,204,000VND to do business.
  • Mrs. L. Thi Huyen (ID Number 10060007), born in 1982, borrows 4,452,000VND to expand her tailoring shop.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Thuy Huyen (ID Number 10060008), born in 1982, borrows 4,028,000VND to raise livestock (pigs and chickens).
  • Mrs. T. Thi Phuong (ID Number 10060009), born in 1986, borrows 4,028,000VND to invest in her breakfast eatery (selling glutenous rice, rice noodles, and bread).

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expanding cosmetic store

loans.name: Thi Phuong's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Phương, sinh năm 1071(Ms 23070050), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi bò, lợn. Hàng ngày chị vẫn đi chợ buôn bán rau còn chồng chị đi phụ xây, hai con chị còn nhỏ đang độ tuổi đi học. Kinh té của gia đình dụa vào thu nhập bình quân  khoảng 2.000.000 vnđ/ tháng. Vợ chồng chị mong muốn dược vay vốn nhiều lần để phát triển kinh tế và anh chị luôn cố gắng làm việc để có tiền hoàn trả vốn và tiết kiệm phòng khi ốm đau. Cùng vay vốn ví chị còn có: 
Lê Thị Mai,sinh năm 2950 (Ms 23070049), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư nuôi lợn. gia đình cô có nhiều nghề nên thu nhập theo ngày khoảng 150.000 vnđ.ngày.
Lê Thị Thủy, sinh năm 1971(Ms 23070052), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư bán hàng.
Nguyễn Thị Hà,sinh năm 1985(Ms 23070041), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Chồng chị làm thợ xây thu nhập khoảng 100.000 vnđ/ ngày.
Nguyễn Thị Nguyệt, sinh năm 1972(Ms 23070080), tham gia vay vốn ở mức: 1.972.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ. Thu nhập theo ngày của chị khoảng 150.000 / ngày.
texts.en:
Mrs. N. Thi Phuong (ID Number 23070050), born 1071, would like to borrow 4,028,000VND to invest in rearing cows and pigs. Everyday, she sells vegetabL. in the market whiL. her husband works at construction sites. Her two children are still young and attending school. Her whoL. family relies on the average monthly income of 2,000,000VND (about 121USD). Her husband and she would like to borrow a few times to improve their family's financial situation. They are working hard to be abL. to repay the loan and save an amount of money for rainy days. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. L. Thi Mai (ID Number 23070049), born in 1950, borrows 4,028,000VND to invest in rearing pigs. Her family has several vocations so the daily income is about 150,000VND (about 9USD).
  • Mrs. L. Thi Thuy (ID Number 23070052), born in 1971, borrows 4,028,000VND to invest in her general store.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Ha (ID Number 23070041), born in 1985, borrows 4,028,000VND to invest in raising chickens. Her husband is a construction worker with the daily income of 100,000VND (about 6USD).
  • Mrs N. Thi Nguyet (ID Number 23070080), born in 1972, borrows 1,972,000VND to do business. Her daily income is about 150,000VND (about 9USD).

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising livestock

loans.name: Davann

texts.en:
Mrs. Davann Y., 44, cooks food to sell from her house in her village. She has been selling food since 2005 and typically earns around US$ 5 per day. Her husband, Mr. Phoun Y., 44, is a carpenter who earns around US$ 7 per day.

Davann has four children, all of whom live at home and help Mr. Phoun with his work, living in Ratanak Commune in the Siem Reap Province. To increase income for the family, Davann wants to sell her food by transporting it to customers' homes. She needs a motorcycle to use as transportation, but lacks the money to purchase one. Hence, she would like to request a loan to buy a motorcycle to use as business transportation.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to use for her business

loans.name: Thi Sơi's Group

texts.vi:
chị Lê thị Sợi năm nay 51 tuổi Ms 01050058 là một phụ nữ rất chịu khó, hàng ngày chị thường thu mua phế liệu của các hộ gia đình khác trong và ngoài thôn, sau đó chế tác, phân loại thành các sản phẩm khác nhau. Công việc này đòi hỏi phải mất nhiều thời gian và công sức, nên hàng ngày chồng, con chị cùng làm với chị, đồng thời con chị vận chuyển hàng đi bán, vì vậy mức thu nhập của gia đình chị thu được mỗi ngày từ 180.000 VND đến 200.000 VND/ ngày. Chị rất thích tham gia vay vốn của Bình Minh CDC vì chị được trả dần, đồng thời được vay vốn thường xuyên không phải thế chấp tài sản, ngoài ra chị còn tiết kiệm được tiền để lo kinh tế cho con, cháu chị được đầy đủ hơn. Chu kỳ này chị đăng ký vay mức 3.186.000 VND để thêm vốn thu mua phế liệu và kinh doanh của gia đình. Các thành viên trong nhóm chị như sau :

  • chị N. thị Phượng Ms 01050054 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn
  • chị Lê thị Tân Ms 01050055 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để đi chợ bán hàng hoa quả
  • chị Nguyễn thị Xoa Ms 01050056 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để mua gỗ sản xuất giường, tủ để bán
  • chị Nguyễn thị Thanh Ms 01050057 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để mua thức ăn gia súc
texts.en:
Mrs. Le Thi Soi (ID Number) 01050058, 51 years old, is a hard-working woman. Everyday, she buys scraps and discarded materials from other families inside and outside her village, then categorizes and sells them. This requires much time and effort, so usually, her husband and her children help her. Her children also transport and sell the materials. Thus, her family's daily income is from 180,000VND to 200,000VND (about 11USD to 12USD). Mrs. Soi likes to borrow through the SEDA Fund because she is allowed to repay the loans on an installment basis, as well as borrow regularly with no collateral required. Besides, she can also save some money to financially help her children and her grand children. This time, she would like to borrow 3,186,000VND to expand her inventory so that she can purchase more scraps and discarded materials. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. Nghiem Thi Phuong (ID Number 01050054) borrows 3,186,000VND to rear pigs.
  • Mrs. Le Thi Tan (ID Number 01050055) borrows 3,186,000VND to sell fruits in the market.
  • Mrs. Nguyen Thi Xoa (ID Number 01050056) borrows 3,186,000VND to purchase wood to make bed frames and wardrobes for sale.
  • Mrs. Nguyen Thi Thanh (ID Number 01050057) borrows 3,186,000VND to purchase animal feed.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy scraps and discarded materials

loans.name: Khairat

texts.en:
Khairat is 26 years and she is married. She became a food seller in 2006. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Khairat now loking for a loan to buy more shoes and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and clothes for her business.

loans.name: Almaz

texts.en:
Almaz A. is a 53-year-old happy father of four children. For eight years, he has been selling spare parts for cars. Almaz wishes to increase his business by offering various types of spare parts for his customers who are permanent clients.

He works to provide his children with all necessary daily things and teaches them the best practices from his experience. He believes one day his small business will transform into a big family business. To reach his goal he has applied for a $1200 USD loan.

loans.use: to increase his business

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok K., age 70,  is an old grocery vendor who lives with two of her children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. On average, she makes around US$4 each day. She told a loan officer that before she became a grocer she grew rice with her husband.  She changed her work to selling groceries because it is easier to make profit. Her husband, Von Veng, age 71, still planting rice and raising pigs to support the family income. Normally, he earns around US$2 each day. Mrs. Sok is requesting a loan of US$750 to purchase a water pump, feed for pigs and increases the the ammount of groceries she is selling from her home.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump, feed for pigs and increases the amount of groceries she is selling

loans.name: Mahammad

texts.en: Mahammad I. is a 50 year old married man with 3 sons and 1 daughter. The children are already married and have their own kids who adore their grandparents. Mahammad has been a cattleman for 6 years, and he has several calves now. His business is stable and generates significant income for the family. He has applied for 1000 USD to purchase four calves. He thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To purchase four calves

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun S., 33, is a true entrepreneur. She has a business with her husband, Heak Phat, 33, making rice mill, growing rice, and raising animals. On average, both of them make around US$3 each day. They have two children who are students. Bun S. is asking a loan of $200 USD to purchase more stone to make rice mill. (Mr. Heak is pictured at his home.)

loans.use: To purchase more stone to make rice mill.

loans.name: Ramile

texts.en: Ramile M. is 25 years old. She is married and has a son. Her mother invited her to help sell clothing at the marketplace and she agreed to the offer. This is how she learned the skills necessary to manage a store. Now she has run the store since 2003. She sells woman's clothes, tights, socks and kerchiefs. Ramile thinks it is important to buy new merchandise so she can stock a wider variety of items, which in turn will attract more customers. She has applied for a loan of $1000 USD. This loan will help her to increase her income, and help her better support her family.

loans.use: To buy new merchandise.

loans.name: Subkhane

texts.en:
Subkhane Q. is 34 years old. She and her husband are raising two sons. She has been breeding cattle for thirteen years. She sells the cattle and dairy products in the local market. She also works as a teacher in a local school but her salary is too small to even cover monthly family needs.

Dairy products sale and calf-breeding generates a stable income, which is the main source of income for the family. Subkhane has applied for a loan in the amount of 1000 USD. She is going to use the loan to purchase a cow for 600 USD and a calf for 300 USD and fodder.

loans.use: to purchase a cow, a calf and fodder.

loans.name: Norn

texts.en: Norn N., 63, is a widowed farmer who resides with three of her children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1980, she has grown rice to earn a living and is able to make less than one dollar per day. She runs her farm just to support her family and she does not normally sell her output for profit. Her children work in a small rice mill and sell the rice to the market. Norn would like to take out a loan of US$300 to purchase more stone to make a mill. (Mrs. Norn is pictured with her daughter)

loans.use: To purchase more stone to make mill.

loans.name: Tamasha

texts.en: Tamasha S.. 52, is married and has four children! For 15 years, Tamasha has been breeding cattle, thanks to her parents who taught her how to raise, breed, and sell calves and dairy products during her childhood. Her elder son is helping her and her husband sells the meat and dairy products in the market. This business provides a stable income for the family. Tamasha applied for s loan of $900 USD. She is planning to expand her business by purchasing   one cow for $800 USD and spending the rest of the loan on fodder. Tamasha is confident that she can pay the loan back on time and says thanks to everyone who will help her to get this loan.

loans.use: To purchase one cow and fodder

loans.name: Makha

texts.fr: Makha est  un jeune menuisier métallique marié et pére de plusieurs .Pour survenir à ses besoins, il a ouvert un atelier où il fabrique des meubles ,portes et autres objets en fer.Le pret obtenu lui permettra de développer son activité en achettant plus de matier premiére  pour répondre à la demende de ses clients.
texts.en:
Makha is a young, married metalworker and the father of several children. To meet his needs, he opened a workshop, where he makes furniture, gates, and other objects out of iron. The obtained loan will enable him to develop his business through the purchase of raw materials to meet the demands of his customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Samoeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Samoeun P. is a 60 year old widow who works as a dessert saleswoman; she earns approximately $3.20 per day. She has four children who all live with. Her oldest daughter, Vanthy Ou, is 34 and is a cleaner for a local NGO. Samoeun sells desserts to many citizens in the village. Her business is going well, and she wants to expand the variety of the desserts she sells. Hence, she needs a loan of $400 to use as capital in order to create a larger variety of desserts. The business is a small group that was formed and Samoeun was chosen to be the leader of two other members Mrs. Somang V. and Mrs. Chou K..

Mrs. Somang V., who is 44, is a staff member of a catholic temple, and her husband, who is 45, is a cameraman. She is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase a camera to replace broken camera, which he uses for his picture service. Mrs. Chou K., who is 51, provides a billing service for phone calls. Chuo is requesting a loan $200 to buy more phone cards to stock and sell for profit. They all live in Ratanak Commune, Battambang Province.

loans.use: use as capital to make dessert for sell

loans.name: Khadija's Tusaidiane Group

texts.en:
Khadija, 22, is widow with two children, ages 3 and 5. She has been selling potatoes, tomatoes, and onions since January 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Khadija is looking for a loan to buy more tomatoes, potatoes, and onions for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mwanakhamis and Tumu.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, potatoes, and onions

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Marie M., 47 ans, mariée avec 05 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois des Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara depuis 4 ans et demi. Son activité consiste à acheter et revendre des thioubs (tissus teintés). Elle veut renforcer son commerce. Ses revenus lui permettent de participer aux charges familiales. <b>Marie sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Marie M., age 47, is married and has five children in her care. She has been a member of the village bank of Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara for four and a half years. Her business consists of buying and selling "thioubs" (dyed fabrics). She wants to bolster her commerce. Her income enables her to help cover family expenses. Marie is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell thioub (dyed fabrics)

loans.name: Caroline

texts.fr: Caroline D., 46 ans, mariée avec 07 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois des Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara depuis 3 ans et demi. Elle veut un prêt pour acheter des porcs et des aliments pour les engraisser et les revendre. Ses revenus lui permettent de participer aux charges familiales. <b>Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Caroline D., 46, is married with 7 children for whom she is responsible. She has been a member of the village bank Catholic Women of Vélingara for three years and a half. She wants a loan to buy pigs and feed to fatten them for re-sale. Her income allows her to help pay family expenses. The loan that she is requesting will be reimbursed at the end of 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: fattening pigs for re-sale

loans.name: Shadida And Zuwena. Group

texts.en:
Shadida is married with 10 children between the ages of 8 and 28 years. She has been a milk and coconut seller since 2005. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Shadida is now looking for a loan to buy more milk and coconuts for re-sale. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Zuwena, who has a business dealing with tailoring.

loans.use: To buy more milk and coconuts for re-sale.

loans.name: Mwajuma's Mwanzo Mgumu. Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 38 years old.  She is married with 6 children between the ages of 7 and 18 years old.  She has been a clothes, home utensils and fish seller since 2004.  Everyday she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.
 
Mwajuma is now looking for a loan to improve her business by adding to her current stock.  She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Sharifa.

loans.use: To improve her business by adding to her current stock.

loans.name: Mrs. Nget Ren Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loA. office, located in Trapeang Kradang Villlage in Takeo Province, consists of ten people; Mrs. Nget R. is the village bank loaner. She is a cow breeder who currently is raising three cows. Her husband, Mr. Koem Nhong, is a construction worker who makes less thA. $2 per day, which is a very little amount of income to support his family. Aside from this business, he owns a hectare-sized field where he cultivates rice to support his household. In order to improve Mrs. Nget R.'s living conditions, she decided to ask for a loA. to buy piglets in order to start a new pig breeding business. Mrs. Nget R. is 40 years old and the mother of two childR., both of whom attend the local school.

This is a village bank loA. consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loA. until the very end of the loA. term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loA. term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy piglets in order to start a new breeding pig business.

loans.name: Mr. Samrith Sokhom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Samrith S. is the president of the village bank that currently serves thirteen people from Pun Phnum Village in the Takeo Province. All the members of this village bank will use the loan for different purposes. Mr. Samrith S. is farmer who owns half a hectare-field where he can cultivate rice. Besides running this business, he sells rice-bran powder in the local village. Since this business is flourishing, he wants to expand it. He has decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice-bran powder to re-sell to his consumers who breed pigs. His wife, Mrs. Pich Bopha, is pig breeder who raises five pigs. Mr. Samrith S. is 36 years old and the father of three children, one of whom is attending the local school. The others are too young to work or study because they are one and five years old. 

One member of this village bank has end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. This member is not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more rice-bran powder to re-sell to his consumers who breed pigs.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr: Mariama M., 48 ans, mariée avec 07 enfants et 05 autres personnes en charge est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Pout à Thiès depuis 2 ans et demi. Son activité consiste à acheter et revendre des fruits et produits locaux comme les pastèques  et les mangues. Elle veut renforcer son commerce de fruit. Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. <b>Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Mariama M., age 48, is married and has seven children and five other people in her care. She has been a member of the village bank of Bayouf Pout in Thiès for two and half years. Her business consists of buying and selling local produce and fruit, such as watermelons and mangoes. She wants to bolster her trade in fruit. Her income enables her to improve her family's living conditions. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell local fruit

loans.name: Mwanaisha's Jiwezeshe Group

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is 30 years old. She is widow with 2 children aged 9 and 5 years old. She has run her own school since 2006. Everyday she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Mwanaisha is now looking for a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with shop owning, juice sales, fish and charcoal sales.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Shahmurad

texts.en: Shahmurad is 30 years old. He is single and lives in Khachaz, Azerbaijan. Five years ago he started a sheep-breeding business. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy a cow and baling presses to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy a cow and baling presses

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu is 48 years old. She is married with 6 children between the ages of 8 and 28 years old. She has been a vegetable seller since 1992. Everyday she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Tatu is now looking for a loan to buy more vegetables for her business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Khadija's Kheri Liwe Group

texts.en:
Khadija is married and has three children ages 9, 4, and 1. She has run her own shop since 2006. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Khadja now hopes for a loan to buy more commodities for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling charcoal, vegetables, and other items.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her business

loans.name: Diouma

texts.fr: Diouma S., 47 ans, mariée avec 04enfants et 03 autres personnes en charge est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Pout à Thiès depuis 3 ans et demi. Elle veut un prêt pour acheter et revendre des tissus bazin et des chaussures. Ses revenus lui permettent de participer aux charges familiales. <b>Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Diouma S., 47, is married with 4 children to raise and 3 other persons, for whom she is also responsible. She has been a member of the village bank of Bayouf Pout in Thiès for three and a half years. She wants a loan to buy "bazin" (hand dyed) cloth and shoes for re-sale. Her income permits her to help support the family. The loan that she is requesting will be reimbursed at the end of 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase and re-sale of cloth and shoes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of more products to add to her inventory

loans.name: Armande Dite Ramata

texts.fr:
Madame Armande dite Ramata Diakité est âgée de 43 ans et vit avec ses 4 enfants et son mari dans une famille nucléaire au quartier Médine de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali.)
Pour des raisons sociales elle ne fréquenta pas l’école et s’est très vite intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus. Madame Armande fait le commerce de pagnes et de parfums.
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de ses activités elle décide de collaborer avec le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 4 ans. Après avoir bouclé 6 prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire) tous correctement remboursés avec une association de son quartier, elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 25 pièces de pagnes Fancy et 18 pièces de pagnes Wax (tissus très prisés en Afrique de l’Ouest).
Elle s’approvisionne généralement à partir de la république du Bénin, des Emirats arabes unies et quelques fois à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Elle effectue ses ventes chez elle à domicile ou en ambulant dans les services au comptant et à crédit payable mensuellement. Sa clientèle est constituée généralement de salariés (hommes et femmes).
Le cycle d’activité est mensuel et envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000FCFA.Son ambition est d’ouvrir une boutique de vente d’habits, de parfums et de chaussures dans la ville de Ségou.
texts.en:
Mrs. Armande dite Ramata Diakité is 43 years old and lives with her four (4) children and husband in a nuclear family in the Medine neighbourhood in the city Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

For social reasonss she did not attend school and very early on became interested with generating income from business activities. Mrs. Diakité is in the business of selling pagnes (decorative cloth) and perfumes.

Concerned about expanding the size of her business, she decided four years ago, to get involved with the loan program at Soro Yiriwaso. She has completed and duly repaid six (6) group loans that were taken out with an association in her neighbourhood. She is on her second individual loan.

She plans to use this loan to purchase 25 pieces of Fancy brand pagne and 18 pieces of Wax brand pagne (cloth that is highly prized in West Africa). She usually buys her stock in the Republic of Benin, the United Arab Emirates and occasionally in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). She conducts her sales from her home and door-to-door service, for cash or credit paid in monthly installments. Her customers are made up generally of workers (both men and women).

Her business cycle is monthly and she expects to realize a monthly profit of 150,000 francs CFA. Her ambition is to open a store to sell clothing, perfume and shoes in the city of Segou.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Wax and Fancy brand pagnes (decorative cloth)

loans.name: Codou

texts.fr: Codou S., 47 ans, mariée avec 07 enfants et 02 autres personnes en charge est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Pout à Thiès depuis 2 ans et demi. Elle veut  renforcer son commerce de fruits locaux (mangues et pastèques). Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. <b>Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Codou S., age 47 and married with seven children and two other people to take care of, has been a member of the Bayouf Pout village bank in Thiès for two and a half years. She wants to expand her business of selling local fruit (mangoes and watermelon). Her income enables her to improve the living conditions of her family. She is requesting a loan which will be repaid after six months in a single installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of local fruit

loans.name: Maryam's Bega Kwa Bega Group

texts.en:
Maryam is married with 5 children between the ages of 10 and 24 years old. She owns a small food vendor store and she is a clothes seller. Everyday she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $155 from her sales.

Maryam is now looking for a loan to buy more food items and clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Sabiha, who has a businesses dealing with charcoal and cassava sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items and clothes for the expansion of her business.

loans.name: Bamoussa Dite Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Bamoussa C. dite Fatoumata est âgée de 57 ans et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit avec son époux ses enfants dans une famille monogame au quartier Angoulême de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative du Mali).
Dès son jeune âge, elle a commencé les activités économiques notamment l’achat vente de divers articles de boutique (tel les cigarettes, les huiles alimentaires, les pates dentifrices, les cadenas, les cartes de jeux, les boites de lait, du lipton, des sachets de lait en poudre etc) depuis maintenant 5 ans. Sa boutique située sur une des artères principales de la ville de Ségou est d’accès facile et est très fréquentée de jour comme de nuit.
Elle travaille avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 3 ans et est à son premier prêt indivuduel, après avoir bouclé six prêts de groupe ( prêt solidaire)  avec une association de son quartier. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 5 sacs de sucres, 50 litres d’huile alimentaire et 6 cartouches de cigarettes auprès des grossistes du grand marché de Ségou. Madame Bamoussa dite Fatoumata vend ses marchandises en détail au comptant et à crédit payable mensuellement aux salariés. 
Elle espère que ce nouveau prêt augmentera le volume de son activité et ses bénéfices. Son ambition est de diversifier ses activités en faisant d’autres types de vente telle la vente de l’essence et du pétrole lampant en détail
texts.en:
Mrs. Bamoussa C. nicknamed Fatoumata, 57, is the mother of 5 children. She lives with her husband and her children in a monogamous family in the Angoulême neighborhood of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali.)

At a young age, she began money-earning activities, and especially has been selling various articles such as cigarettes, cooking oils, toothpaste, padlocks, playing cards, tins of milk, Lipton tea, bags of powdered milk, etc. for 5 years now. Her little shop is located on one of the principal roads of the town of Ségou, easy to get to, much frequented day and night.

She has been working with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for 3 years and is now on her first individual loan, having received 6 group loans through an association in her neighborhood. All her preceding loans were correctly repaid.

She intends to use this loan to buy 5 sacks of sugar, 50 liters of cooking oil, and 6 cartons of cigarettes from the wholesalers in the big open-air market in Ségou. Bamoussa (known as Fatoumata) sells her merchandise retail, for cash or on credit, repaid monthly for those having salaries.

She hopes that this new loan will increase the volume of her business and thus her profit from it. Her ambition is to diversify her business by retailing other things such as gasoline and kerosene.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items to re-sell

loans.name: Tukae's Tushirikiane Group

texts.en:
Tukae, 30 years old and married, has owned a general store since 2001. Working daily from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m., she can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from sales.

Tukae now hopes for a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses in clothes and cosmetics sales, vegetables sales, cassava sales and shop ownership.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Unity 2036-2 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Filta P..  She is currently in the business of selling tea and is requesting a loan to buy more sugar.  

Filta is 45 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant.  She has 3 children ranging from age 9 to 21 and her children go to school.  Each week, Filta makes approximately 70 Sudanese pounds in profits, and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more sugar.  

Filta is joined in her small group by Mary Abddalla, Susan N., Julia A. and Wilma Wulujaali.  Mary Abddalla has a business selling bread at the market and wants to expand her business.  Susan N. is currently operating a business in selling goods like bedsheets, soap and shoes at the market and wants a loan to expand her business.  Julia A. operates a business selling fried eggs, meat, beans, fresh fish, etc. at the hotel and wants to expand the hotel.  Wilma Wulujaali is currently in the business of selling chacoal at home and is requesting a loan to expand the business.

loans.use: To buy more sugar

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata D. est âgée de 30 ans, et vit dans une famille monogame avec son enfant et son époux au quartier Missira de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Afin de s’insérer dans la vie économique, elle décida de faire de la tresse des cheveux son activité en plus de l’achat et de la vente de mèches (cheveux artificiels). Elle a apprise la tresse des cheveux dès sa jeune enfance auprès de sa mère. Employée au Salon Jumelle Coiffure (situé au bord de l’un des boulevards les plus fréquentés de la ville de Ségou) depuis maintenant trois (3) ans, Madame Fatoumata ne tarie pas d’éloges et de renoms grâce à la qualité de ses tresses et de ses marchandises.
Pour maintenir sa clientèle de plus en plus importante, elle décide de rejoindre le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel elle est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter sur place au grand marché de la ville de Ségou, 3 cartons de mèches de différentes qualités et des robes pour mariés (qui sont destinées à la location). Ainsi elle disposera de toute la gamme de produits dont les femmes auront besoin lors des week end et des cérémonies. Les nouvelles mariées se feront tresser et habiller directement sur place.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour contribuer aux dépenses de la famille,  payer les intérêts de son prêt et  investir le reste dans son activité. Son ambition est d’avoir un salon de coiffure avec des matériels modernes..
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata D. is 30 and lives in a monogamous family with her husband and child in the Missira neighborhood of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

So as to get a footing in economic life, she decided to do hair braiding and to sell hair extensions. She learned hair braiding from her mother when she was just a child. An employee of the Jumelle Beauty Salon (situated on one of the most traveled boulevards of the town of Ségou) for three years now, Fatoumata wins lots of praise and renown because of the quality of her braids and of the products she sells.

To maintain her ever growing clientele, she decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso with whom she is on her first individual loan.

With this loan she intends to buy, right in the big market of the town of Ségou, 3 cases of hair extensions of various qualities and some bridal gowns (that she intends to rent out.) Thus she will have at her fingertips a whole range of products that women need for weekends and ceremonies. Recently married women can have their hair done and are dressed directly on the premises.

With this loan, she envisages making a monthly profit of 40,000 F CFA which she will use to help support her family, to make payments on the loan, and she hopes to invest any remainder into her business. Her ambition is to have her very own beauty salon with modern conveniences.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of hair extensions and dresses for brides

loans.name: Zuhura's Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en:
Zuhura is married with 4 children between the ages of 16 and 25 and years old. She has been a clothes seller since 2005. Everyday she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Zuhura is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes for the expansion of her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Asha, who has a business dealing with shop owning.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for the expansion of her business.

loans.name: Djamadjigui (The Hope Of The World) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djamadjigui est composé de cinq (5) femmes mariées vivant en générale dans des foyers polygames traditionnels élargis avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, 2 enfants et résidant dans le quartier Fadougala du village Thien Bamanan de Ségou (quatrième région économique du Mali).
Ces femmes exercent le commerce de produits maraîchers tel l’oignon et la tomate. Unies par des relations professionnelles et de voisinage elles ont décidé ensemble (après avoir vu l’exemple de certaines femmes du village à travers le prêt solidaire) d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 400kg d’oignon et 2 baignoires de tomate fraîche sur place au village et à la foire de Markala (les dimanches) auprès des forains venant des préfectures de Niono (région de Ségou) et de Sikasso (région de Sikasso). Cette opération est hebdomadaire.
Ces produits sont ensuite vendus au comptant ou en détail dans les différents quartiers de Markala ou sur place au village de Thien Bamanan à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes.
 Les femmes du groupe Djamadjigui espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 18.335 FCFA mensuel qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, et renforcer le fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The Djamadjigui group is composed of 5 married women who live, in general, in polygamous traditional extended households. They have an average age of 38 and 2 children on average, and they live in the Fadougala neighborhood of the village Thien Bamanan near Ségou (fourth economic region of Mali). These women sell vegetables such as onions and tomatoes.

United by professional ties and living in the same neighborhood, they decided together (after having seen the example of what certain village women have done through a group loan) to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their first group loan.

They intend to use the loan to buy 400 kg of onions and 2 basins of fresh tomatoes in the village and at the fair of Markala (Sundays) from merchants coming from the prefectures of Niono (Ségou region) and from Sikasso (Sikasso region). This happens weekly.

These products are then sold for cash or retailed in the various districts of Markala or on the village square of Thien Bamanan to a clientele composed mainly of women.

Each of the women of the Djamadjigui group hopes to make a profit of 18,335 F CFA per month, which will be used to make payments on the loan and bolster their working capital.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of onions and fresh tomatoes for re-sale

loans.name: Philomène

texts.fr: Philomène D., 54 ans, mariée avec 05enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara depuis 4ans et demi. Elle veut un prêt pour acheter et revendre de la pâte d'arachide et des thioub (tissus teintés) . Ses revenus lui permettent de contribuer à la prise en charge de sa famille. <b>Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Philomène D., 54 years old and married with five children, has been a member of the Vélingara Catholic Women’s village bank for four and a half years. Philomène wants a loan to purchase peanut butter and thioub, a dyed Sengalese fabric, for resale. The profits will permit her to contribute to the support of her family. The loan which she is requesting will be repaid in a lump sum in six months’ time.

Translated from French by Joyce K., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of peanut butter and thioub fabric

loans.name: Maryam Ali Bega Kwa Bega Group

texts.en:
Maryam is 37 years old. She is married with 5 children between the ages of 1 and 16 years old. She has been a firewood and vegetable seller since 2005. Everyday she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Maryam is now looking for a loan to expand her business by increasing her current stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mtumwa, who has a business dealing with coconut, handbag and cassava sales.

loans.use: To expand her business by increasing her current stock.

loans.name: Sinsinbéré (Le Pilier Central Group

texts.fr:
Sinsinbéré est un regroupement de six femmes mariées et deux veuves ayant une moyenne d’âge de 49 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Diamambougou du village de Thien Bamanan de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Les membres du groupe Sinsinbéré sont liés par des liens de parenté et d’amitié.
Elles exercent le commerce des condiments alimentaires tel les feuilles de baobab séchées, des oignons, du sounbala, des piments, de l’aubergine etc. En raison de la confiance mutuelle, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso (suite à des informations fournies par la monitrice du jardin d’enfant de Markala). Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe (crédit solidaire) avec l’institution après avoir correctement remboursé les deux premiers.
Avec ce nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, une importante quantité de condiments alimentaires (2 paniers d’oignon, 5 paniers de piments et une quantité importante d’aubergine). 
Elles s’approvisionnent sur place au village, à la foire de Markala et dans le village de Sansanding auprès de forains venant de Niono et de Sikasso. 
La vente de ces articles se fait généralement au village en détail au comptant et à crédit. Elles étalent les marchandises sur la place publique du village ou se promènent avec dans les quartiers de Markala. La clientèle est essentiellement composée de femmes.
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 11.000FCFA qu’elles utiliseront à aider leurs maris à subvenir aux charges de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
Elles ont pour ambition de se procurer d’une charrette et d’un âne afin de faciliter le transport   de leurs marchandises entre les foires.
texts.en:
Sinsinbéré is a group of six married women and two widows averaging 49 years of age and three children. Most of them live in large extended traditional families in the Diamambougou district of Thien Bamanan de Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The group members are linked by ties of family and friendship. They do commerce in condiments, such as dried baobab leaves, onions, sounbala (pounded and fermented seeds or beans), chili peppers, eggplant, etc. Because of their mutual trust, they decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso (following the information furnished by the trainer at the Markala kindergarten). They are on their third group loan (solidarity loan) with the institution after having correctly repaid the first two. With this new loan, they intend to buy a large quantity of condiments (two baskets of onions, five baskets of chilis, and a sizable quantity of eggplant). They get their supplies locally in the village, at the Markala fair, and in the village of Sansanding from traveling vendors coming from Niono and from Sikasso. The sales of these good are generally made in the village at the retail level, cash and credit accepted. They spread out their goods in the village square or walk among the districts of Markala. Their customer base is essentially composed of women. They hope to realize a monthly profit of 11,000 francs CFA that they will use to assist their husbands in providing for the family and to invest the remainder in the business. Their ambition is to procure for themselves a cart and a donkey in order to facilitate transporting their goods from fair to fair.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Bélange

texts.fr: Bélange D., 31 ans, mariée avec 03 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara depuis 4ans et demi. Elle veut acheter et revendre des tissus (tissus teintés et tissus de saint). Ses revenus lui permettent de contribuer à la prise en charge de sa famille. <b>Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Bélange D., 31, is married and raising 3 children. She has been a member of the village bank Catholic Women of Vélingara for four and a half years. She wants to buy and re-sell cloth (batik-style cloth and cloth with pictures of saints). Her income makes it possible for her to contribute to covering family expenses. The loan that she is requesting will be repaid at the end of 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of cloth

loans.name: Unity 2036-3 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Ludia J..  She is currently in the business of selling flour and is requesting a loan to expand the business.  

Ludia is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is an accountant.  She has 5 children ranging from age 9 to 21 and her children go to school.  Each week, Ludia makes approximately 100 Sudanese pounds in profits, and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.  

Ludia is joined in her small group by Margret Elusipa, Alice A., Rejoice A. and Josephine J..  Margret Elusipa has a business selling bread at the market and wants to expand her business.  Alice A. is currently operating a business selling local brew and wants a loan to expand her business.  Rejoice A. operates a business selling tomatoes at home and wants to buy a generator for sale.  Josephine J. is currently in the business of selling beans and maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to expand the business.

loans.use: expand the business

loans.name: Haoua

texts.fr:
Madame Haoua Traoré âgée de 48 ans est mariée et est mère de trois (3) enfants. Elle vit dans une famille monogame avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école, elle a très tôt commencé les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère pour finalement se consacrer au commerce de bois de chauffe et du charbon de bois depuis maintenant 11 ans.
En relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 2 ans, elle a déjà bénéficié de 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et est à son premier prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 30 chargements de bois de chauffe, 40 sacs de charbon de bois (en vue de constituer un stock pour palier une éventuelle rupture).
Son approvisionnement se fait exclusivement dans le village de Sanando (situé sur l’axe routier Bamako Ségou) auprès des paysans spécialisés (et ayant une autorisation des structures compétentes de l’état) dans la coupe de bois de chauffe et la production du charbon de bois. Le bois et les sacs de charbon achetés sont stockés dans un endroit emménagé dans la cour de la concession familiale à l’abri de la pluie. La vente se fait à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes de son quartier en détail et surtout au comptant..
Etant la seule vendeuse de ces articles du quartier donc sans concurrence, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de  75 000 FCFA. et rêve de devenir grossiste et construire une deuxième maison d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Haoua Traoré, 48, is married and the mother of 3 children. She lives in a monogamous family with her children and her husband in the Darsalam neighborhood of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali.)

Not having had the good fortune to attend school, she began at a young age to earn money alongside her mother and ended up selling firewood and charcoal, a business she has been in for 11 years now.

A member of Soro Yiriwaso for 2 years, she has already received a share of 3 group loans and is now on her first individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed. This loan will be used to buy 30 loads of firewood and 40 sacks of charcoal (so as to stock up lest there be shortages.)

She does her buying exclusively in the village of Sanando (situated on the road from Bamako to Ségou) from rural people (who have an authorization from the State) specialized in cutting firewood and producing charcoal. The wood and the sacks of charcoal she buys are stored in a specially prepared place in the family compound, well away from rain. She sells to a clientele that is composed of women and men from her neighborhood, retail and on a cash basis.

Being the only one in her neighborhood who sells these items and thus having no competitors, she expects to make a profit of 75,000 F CFA and she dreams of becoming a wholesaler and of building a second house.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood and charcoal

loans.name: Tidiane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Tidiane K. est âgé de 23 ans est célibataire et père   d’un (1) enfant. Il vit dans le quartier Darsalam de la ville Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali), dans une famille traditionnelle avec son enfant, ses frères et soeurs, son père, sa mère et les autres parents 
Pour des raisons de pauvreté, Tidiane l’aîné de la famille fut obligé d’abandonner les études et entamer une activité génératrice de revenus afin de venir en appui à ses parents (comme l’exige la tradition). Ainsi il entama l’apprentissage du métier de tailleur auprès de plusieurs maîtres tailleurs de la ville de Ségou puis de Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Après huit (8) ans d’expériences, il devient un maître tailleur connu de tout Ségou. Son atélier  situé au quartier Darsalam est très visité par une clientèle très variée.
Afin de satisfaire les demandes de plus en plus croissantes et exigeantes de cette clientèle, il décide d’intégrer le programme de crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle  il est à son premier prêt individuel. 
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter une nouvelle machine à coudre et une armoire pour la garde des tissus et habits.
Monsieur Tidiane Keïta compte  réaliser  50.000 FCFA  qui sera utilisé pour subvenir essentiellement aux besoins de sa famille très nombreuse.
texts.en:
