Mr. Tidiane K., 23, is single and the father of one child. He lives in the neighborhood called Darsalam of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali), in a traditional family with his child, his brothers and sisters, his father, mother, and other relatives.

Due to poverty, Tidiane, the eldest in the family, was obliged to leave his studies and begin to earn money so as to help his parents (as tradition demands). Thus he took up an apprenticeship with several master tailors of the town of Ségou, then of Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali). After 8 years of experience, he became a master tailor, known by all in Ségou. His workshop situtated in the Darsalam neighborhood is frequented by a very varied clientele.

So as to satisfy the growing demands of these exigent customers, he decided to become a member of the credit program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom he is presently on his first individual loan. He plans to use this loan to buy a new sewing machine and a wardrobe for his workshop to keep his cloth and suits.

Mr. Tidiane Keïta expects to make 50,000 F CFA which he will use essentially for the basic needs of his very large family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a sewing machine and a wardrobe

loans.name: Paulette Lucie

texts.fr: Paulette Lucie S., 48 ans, mariée avec 05 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois des Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara depuis 4 ans et demi. Elle vend des glaces et des crèmes glacées et élève aussi des porcs en guise d’activité secondaire. Paulette veut acheter du pain de singe et du sucre pour faire des crèmes glacées à vendre et du son de mil pour engraisser des porcs à revendre. Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent de participer aux charges familiales. <b>Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Paulette Lucie S. is 48 years old, married and responsible for 5 children. She has been a village board member of the Catholic Women of Velingara for four and a half years. She sells ice and ice cream and also raises pigs as a secondary business activity. Paulette would like to buy baobab fruit and sugar to make ice cream for sale and millet to fatten her pigs for resale. The profits pulled from this business will permit her to contribute to the family expenses. She is requesting a loan which will be repaid at the end of six months in one single payment.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of ice cream and raising pigs

loans.name: Isabel

texts.pt:
Isabel M. nasceu na província de Gaza tem 48 anos de idade é casada maritalmente e mãe de 5 filhos e o mais velhos tem 29 anos de idade e os mais novos são gémeos e estudam na 9ªclasse, para alem dos seus filhos sustenta dois sobrinhos que vive com eles.

Isabel estudou ate 6ªclasse e parou por falta de condições financeiras por parte dos seus pais, em 1977 incorporou se nas forças armadas de Moçambique e em 1981 foi desmobilizada, desde 1981 trabalha com civil no hospital militar como assistente  administrativa.

Funcionaria do ministério da defesa a Maios de 20 anos com um horário das 7:30 ate as 15:30 tem um salário mensal de 2779,21mt . este é o terceiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e primeiro no Kiva nunca teve noutras instituições. Os dois primeiros foram aplicados na construção da sua residência e com pretende fazer os acabamentos e construção do muro de vedação.

Assim num futuro tão breve pretende mobilar a casa e conta com apoio de credito.
texts.en:
Isabel M. was born in the Gaza province and is 48 years old. She is married and the mother of 5 children. The oldest is 29 years old, and the youngest are twins studying in 9th grade. In addition to her children, she supports two nephews who live with them.

Isabel studied through 6th grade and then stopped on account of her parents’ lack of financial resources. In 1977 she joined the Mozambique armed forces and was discharged in 1981. Since 1981 she has worked as a civilian, as an administrative assistant in a military hospital.

An employee of the Department of Defense for more than 20 years, Isabel works from 7:30am to 3:30pm and earns 2,779.21 meticais (MTn) per month. This is her third loan from Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner) and her first with Kiva. She has never had a loan with other institutions. She used the first two loans for the construction of her house, and she intends to use this loan to do the finishing work and build a wall around the house.

In the very near future, Isabel plans to furnish her house with the help of a loan.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials for her house

loans.name: Jigiya (Support) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre (4) membres du groupe Jigiya sont toutes des femmes mariées vivant dans des foyers polygames avec en moyenne 35 ans et 4 enfants. Elles résident dans le village de Tentou de la sous préfecture de Ouéléssébougou (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues par des liens d’amitié et de famille et font de la transformation des graines de néré en Soumbala. (une pâte alimentaire de couleur noirâtre très appréciée et sollicitée dans la fabrication des sauces alimentaires dans la sous région Ouest africaine). Elles ont appris la production du Soumbala dès le bas âge auprès de leurs mères c'est-à-dire de génération en génération.
Dans le souci de satisfaire une clientèle de plus en plus importante, elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire) et tous les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter chacune, 450 kilogrammes de grains de néré (arbre oléagineux de la région sahélienne) et du bois de chauffe. Les grains de néré après achat sont bouillies, pilées et pétries afin de donner la dite pâte alimentaire. Le cycle (production et vente) dure trois (3) semaines.
Le soumbala ainsi fait est acheminé sur Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) souvent en république du Sénégal pour être vendu au comptant ou à crédit à des grossistes. La vente une fois effective, elles achètent des pagnes wax pour venir les revendre au village.
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 28.000 FCFA chacune et ambitionnent devenir des grandes productrices afin de ravitailler toute la sous région en Soumbala.
texts.en:
The four members of Jigiya group are all married women living in polygamous households. They are on average 35 years old and have 4 children. They live in the village of Tentou in the Sous-prefecture of Ouéléssébougou (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met because of bonds of friendship and family and they process néré seeds into "soumbala" (a black-colored paste that is much appreciated and is essential to making sauces in this area of West Africa.) They learned how to make soumbala from their mothers when they were young, that is, from generation to generation.

Intent on satisfying an ever growing clientele, they decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso. They are now on their fourth group loan, with all the earlier loans correctly reimbursed.

With this loan, each of them intends to buy 450 kg of néré grains (which come from an oil-producing tree native to the Sahel region) and firewood. The néré seeds are boiled and then ground and crushed in mortars to make the paste. The cycle production and sale) takes 3 weeks.

The soumbala that they produce is goes to Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali) and often to Senegal to be sold for cash or credit to wholesalers. Once they have concluded the sale, they buy high quality "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored batik-like cloth) that they re-sell in the village.

They each expect to make a monthly average profit of 28,000 F CFA and their ambition is to become important producers who supply the whole region with soumbala.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of raw materials (néré seeds and firewood) to produce soumbala

loans.name: Zokhra

texts.en: Zokhra Quliyev is a 44 year old loving mother of three children. Zokhra breeds calves for meat production, and she has been in this business from a very young age. As her parents were also farmers, a hard life pushed her to follow the same business. She took this business in hand and it has started to provide her with an income. As it is only one financial source for her family, she tries very hard to keep the calves in good condition. Also, her husband is very polite to his clients who buy meat. Zokhra is planning to expand her business via the purchase of 3 calves for 300 USD each and 100 USD for feed. She believes that you can help her to improve her life.

loans.use: To purchase 3 calves and feed

loans.name: Kotognotala (Compromis Mutuel) Group

texts.fr:
Kotognotala est un regroupement de sept (7) femmes toutes mariées et vivent dans des foyers polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et 6 enfants. Elles résident toutes à Ouéléssébougou (une sous préfecture de la deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parenté et font essentiellement la production et vente de nourritures (soumbala et de boissons locales).
C’est dans la recherche des ressources financières complémentaires que ce groupe de femmes a décidé de collaborer avec l’institution. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe), le groupe est à son deuxième prêt.
Ces femmes comptent acheter chacune avec ce nouveau prêt 250 kilogrammes de grains de néré, un important stock de bois de chauffe et divers autres articles. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place aux marchés de Ouelessébougou et environnants pour les graines de néré (arbre oléagineux de la zone sahélienne).Quant aux divers articles (jus en poudre, dah, sucre, sachets plastiques) elles les achètent à partir de Bamako (capitale de république du Mali) et quelques fois sur place. Elles effectuent leurs ventes sur place au village aux résidants et aux revendeurs venant des grandes villes telle Bougouni, Bamako et Kati. Les ventes sont effectuées généralement au comptant.  
Elles comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 36.000 FCFA.qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour renforcer le fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
Kotognotala (meaning "mutual compromise") is a group of seven women who are all married. They live in polygamous households and average 38 years of age and six children. They all reside in Ouéléssébougou (a sub-prefecture of the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other by ties of community and blood. Essentially they produce and sell food (soumbala, which is a fermented paste made from locust seeds; and local beverages). The search for supplementary financial resources is the reason why this group of women has decided to collaborate with the institution After having correctly repaid the first solidarity loan (group loan), the group is on its second loan. These women each intend to use this new loan to buy 250 kg of néré seeds (locust seeds), a large stock of firewood, and various other articles. They get their supplies locally at the marketplaces of Ouelessébougou and its surrounding areas for néré seeds (from a tree that is a source of oil in sub-Saharan regions). As for the various articles, such as powdered juices, dah (fried hibiscus blossoms), sugar, and plastic bags, they buy them from Bamako (capital of Mali) and sometimes locally. They make their sales locally out of homes in the village and to retailers who come from the big cities, such as Bougouni, Bamako, and Kati. Sales are generally made in cash. They each intend to realize a monthly profit of 36,000 francs CFA, which will be used essentially to bolster their working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making soumbala and local soft drinks

loans.name: Novruz

texts.en:
Novruz S. is a 61-year-old farmer, married with two grown sons. For thirteen years he has raised sheep. He has very strong health that's allow him to pasture his sheep. His two sons help him by selling sheep once a week in the local bazaar. He is still is very poor and lives in very hard conditions.

He would like to expand his business and purchase 15 sheep for 60 USD each, and fodder. He also wants to improve the winter conditions for sheep. He wishes to improve his life so that one day he could have a big herd of sheep.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and fodder

loans.name: Sankorota (Le Rehaussement) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sankorota sont des femmes mariées vivant dans des foyers polygames avec en moyenne 40 ans, 4 enfants et qui habitent Tentou (un village de la sous préfecture de  Ouéléssébougou deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues par des liens professionnel et d’amitié et font toutes la production d’une pâte alimentaire appelée le Soumbala. Cette activité de transformation des graines de néré en Soumbala est une somme de connaissances qui est transmise de mère en fille. 
Afin d’augmenter la taille de leurs productions, ce groupe de femmes a décidé ensemble d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir remboursé sans difficulté leur premier prêt, le groupe est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
Avec ce nouveau prêt, les femmes du groupe Sankorota achèteront chacune 300 kilogrammes de graines de néré (arbre oléagineux de la région sahélienne) et de bois de chauffe pour la cuisson des graines. Le cycle de production et de vente dure en moyenne trois (3) semaines.
Le soumbala finit est acheminé sur Bamako (capitale du Mali) pour être vendu en espèce et souvent à crédit aux revendeurs des marchés de cette ville.
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen par cycle de 20.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sankorota are married women living in polygamous households. They average 40 years of age and four children, and they live in Tentou (a village in the sub-prefecture of Ouéléssébougou, second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other by ties of profession and friendship. Their work involves making an edible paste or dough called "soumbala". This work of transforming néré seeds into soumbala is a body of knowledge that is passed down from mother to daughter. In order to increase their production, this members of this group have decided together to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After having repaid their first loan without difficulty, the group members are now on their second solidarity loan (group loan). With this new loan, they will each buy 300 kg of néré seeds (from the néré tree, which is a source of oil in sub-Saharan regions) and firewood for cooking the seeds. The production and selling cycle lasts three weeks on average. The finished soumbala is taken to Bamako (capital of Mali) to be sold for cash or often on credit to retailers at the marketplaces in this city. They hope to realize a per-cycle profit of 20,000 francs CFA, which will be used to pay the loan interest, to help cover family expenses, and to invest the remainder in the business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy néré seeds and firewood

loans.name: Aladdin

texts.en: Aladdin H. is 46 years old. He is married with three children. His wife looks after the house and the kids. Aladdin supports his family by breeding cattle, which he sells for meat. He started his business in 1982 when he was very young. Cattle-breeding is the main source of income for the family and generates the income necessary to allow Aladdin to support his family and improve their living conditions. Now he has applied for a 1200 USD loan, which he is planning to use on purchasing one milking cow for 600 USD and two calves for 300 USD each.

loans.use: To purchase one cow and two calves

loans.name: Arif

texts.en: Arif H., 50, sells milk and yoghurt to the local people and to dairy factories. He is married and has three children. Currently, he has one cow that is pregnant! He is so excited about this! Arif is quite experienced because he has been in this business for eight years. Already this business is the main source of income for the family. His main profession is as an agronomist. This training helps him to run his current business. Arif needs more cows to increase his income and improve his living conditions. For this purpose, he requests  a loan of $1200 USD to purchase two cows at an estimated cost of $600 USD each. This is Arif’s first loan. He is sure he will be able to pay it back on time, and he thanks you for your trust in him.

loans.use: To purchase two cows

loans.name: Tamella

texts.en:
Tamella A. is 48 years old. She is married and has two lovely daughters. With persistence, dedication, and the help of her husband, they have been able to cultivate their land.

They grow corn and sell it to merchants in the local bazaar. Tamella would like to manage her land more efficiently, which will make it more productive and will enable her to grow different varieties of crops. For this purpose she has applied for a loan in the amount of 1200 USD for purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer. Let's help Tamella continue with her noble intention of improving the quality of life of her family.

loans.use: purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Gulush

texts.en: Gulush R. is a 61-year-old grandmother and the mother of two sons. She is very proud that, even at this age, she is able to manage her own business. She started her business in 2000 and since that time it has been her main source of income. She currently has two cows and her main income comes from selling dairy products. She and her husband are on a pension now. Gulush is planning to purchase one additional cow to increase her income. For this purpose she requests  a loan of $800 USD. This is his first request for loan, and she promises to manage the loan without violations and delinquency.

loans.use: To purchase one cow and fodder

loans.name: Zarkhanim

texts.en:
Zarkhanim Q. is 55 years old. She is married and the loving mother of seven children! She started her business in order to help her husband with the household expenses, especially because it was very hard to cover the basic needs of such a large family. The main purpose of her hard work is to provide her children with a good education.

She started her business in 2004 after her cousin told her that the sale of women's clothing was a good business. Zarkhanim sells her goods in a small shop near her house. She shows very good taste in choosing the clothing she buys and amazing marketing skills in convincing her clients which clothing they should buy. She has applied for a loan of $1000 USD to expand her business by purchasing additional seasonal clothes.

loans.use: to purchase additional seasonal clothes

loans.name: Bahar

texts.en: Bahar S., 34, is married and has three children. Her main activity is selling milk and yoghurt to the local people. Generally her day starts early in the morning and lasts until late at night. This business has been the main source of income for her family for the past six years. Bahar is planning to increase the size of her business by purchasing one more cow. The additional cow will help her to sell more milk and yoghurt each day so she can increase her income. She thanks everyone for their trust and support.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for milking

loans.name: Huseyn

texts.en:
Huseyn I. is a 30-year-old cattleman. He is married and has one son who is studying at school. His main source of income is breeding calves. He started his business in 1999; since that time he has learned lots from his parents, who are former farmers. Having been in the business for so long, Huseyn believes the business is profitable and generates a stable income. 

Now he is planning to expand his business and purchase three additional calves for 300 USD each, and to use 100 USD to purchase fodder. Borrowing for the first time, Huseyn thanks everyone supporting him and promises to be accurate in the loan repayment.

loans.use: To purchase calves and fodder

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina M. is 53 years old and a widow with four children, ages 25, 23, 20, and 18. She works hard running two businesses: selling clothes and running a charcoal shop in Mbagala. She started both of these businesses in 2000 and works daily from 8 am until 6 pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of about $173.

This will be Regina's sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase the stock of both of her businesses. She has paid back all the loans successfully and promptly. With the loan she hopes to receive now, she will continue to expand her stock of clothes and charcoal.

loans.use: To increase her stock of clothing and charcoal.

loans.name: Kiazia

texts.en:
Kiazia A. is 27 and married. She has four children who are 12, 10, 6, and 3 from her first husband, who unfortunately passed away. Kiazia previously sold Swahili fabrics called vitenge and kangas but she switched to a wholesale drinks business in 2007. She sells soda, juice, and water to smaller shops in Dar es Salaam. She works daily from 7 am until 6 pm, and is able to earn a monthly profit between $216 and $259.

This will be Kiazia's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first two loans to increase her stock and has paid both loans back successfully. With the loan she hopes to receive now, she intends to use it similarly to increase the stock of her shop.

loans.use: To increase stock of drinks in her shop.

loans.name: Léocadie

texts.fr: Léocadie D., 54ans, mariée avec 05 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois des Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara depuis 4 ans et demi. Elle veut acheter des porcs et des aliments (son de mil) pour les engraisser et les revendre. Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent de participer aux charges familiales. <b>Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Léocadie D., age 54, is married and has five children in her care. She has been a member of the village bank of Femmes Catholiques de Vélingara for four and a half years. She want to buy pigs and feed (millet bran) to fatten them and then to sell them. The income derived from her business enables her to help cover family expenses. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To raise pigs

loans.name: Ndèye Fallo

texts.fr: Ndèye Fallo Ndao, 52 ans, mariée avec 07 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Pout à Thiès depuis 3 ans. Son activité consiste à acheter et revendre des fruits locaux comme les pastèques, les mandarines et les mangues selon la saison. Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. <b>Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Ndèye Fallo Ndao, age 52, is married and has seven children in her care. She has been a member of the village bank of Bayouf Pout in Thiès for three years. Her business consists of buying and reselling local fruit, like watermelons, mandarin oranges, and mangoes according the season. Her income enables her to improve her family's living conditions. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell local fruit

loans.name: Ushirikiano Kiburugwa Group

texts.en:
Saumu S. is 40 and married. She has three children, ages 14, 9, and 8. She opened a shop in 2000 where she sells clothes and general household items such as food. She works daily from 7am until 8pm and earns a monthly profit of about $86.

This will be Saumu's sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase the stock of her shop and has paid them all back successfully. However, the employee who was working for her shop by selling door-to-door recently stole many of her things and disappeared. Therefore, she will be using this loan to restock her shop and recover from the losses of the robbery.

Saumu is part of subgroup F of the Ushirikiano Kiburugwa Group. The members of the group hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. In the picture, Saumu is with her subgroup and is sitting third from the left in pink. Other members of the subgroup include Mwajuma A. (food vendor), Chiku S. (fruit and vegetable stand), Jamira Y. (tea seller), Tatu O. (food vendor) and Mariam S. (fruit stand).

loans.use: Restock general store.

loans.name: Waline

texts.fr: Waline D., 40 ans, mariée avec 05enfants et 03 autres personnes en charge est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Pout à Thiès depuis 3 ans et demi. Elle veut  renforcer son commerce de fruits locaux (mangues et pastèques). Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. <b>Waline sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Waline D., age 40, is married and has five children and three other people in her care. She has been a member of the village bank of Bayouf Pout in Thiès for three and a half years. She wants to bolster her commerce in local fruit (mangoes and watermelons). The income derived from her commerce will enable her to improve her family's living conditions. Waline is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell local fruit

loans.name: Gnagna

texts.fr: Gnagna D., 54 ans, mariée avec 07 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Pout à Thiès depuis 3 ans. Elle veut  renforcer son commerce de fruits locaux (mangues et mandarines). Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent de participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille. <b>Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Gnagna D., 54, is married and raising 7 children. She has been a member of the village bank of Bayouf Pout in Thiès for three years. She wants to bolster her little business selling local fruit (mangos and mandarine oranges). The income she makes from her business allows her to participate in paying the family's daily expenses. She is requesting a loan that will be reimbursed at the end of six months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of local fruit

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr: Aminata est une femme mariée ,elle s' active dans la vente de vétements pour jeunes filles depuis plusieurs années.Elle a monté son  commerce sur fonds propres.Sa principale clientelle est constituée des filles des établissements scolaires.Le pret obtenu lui permettra de renouveller sa collection pour les rentrées scolaires.
texts.en:
Aminata is a married woman. She has been selling girls' clothes for several years. She got her business going with her own funds. Her principal clientele is constituted of school girls. This loan will allow her to freshen up her collection of clothing inventory for the beginning school year.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Marie N., 48 ans, mariée est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Pout à Thiès depuis 6 ans. Elle veut un prêt pour acheter et revendre des fruits locaux comme les mandarines, les clémentines, les oranges, les  pastèques et les mangues selon la saison. Cette activité lui permet d’avoir des revenus pour prendre en charge les besoins de sa famille. <b> Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Marie N., age 48, is married and has been a member of the village bank of Bayouf Pout in Thiès for six years. She wants a loan to buy and resell local fruit, such as mandarin oranges, clementines, oranges, watermelons, and mangoes, according to the season. This business enables her to have an income for taking care of family needs. The loan that she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell local fruit

loans.name: Woroba

texts.fr: Woroba N., 63 ans, mariée avec 07 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Pout à Thiès depuis 3 ans. Elle veut  renforcer son commerce de fruits locaux comme les pastèques, les mangues, les oranges, les mandarines et clémentines selon la saison.. Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent de participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille. <b>Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Woroba N., age 63, is married and has seven children. She has been a member of the village bank of Bayouf Pout in Thiès for three years. She wants to bolster her commerce in local fruit, such as watermelon, mangoes, oranges, mandarin oranges, and clementines according to the season. The income derived from her commerce will allow her to help cover day-to-day family expenses. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell local fruit

loans.name: Astou

texts.fr: Astou D., 46 ans, mariée avec 02 enfants et 03 autres en charge est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Pout à Thiès depuis 7 ans et demi. Elle veut  renforcer son commerce de fruits locaux comme les pastèques, les mangues, les oranges, les mandarines et clémentines selon la saison. Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. <b>Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Astou D., 46, is married with two children and is responsible for three others. She has been a member of the village bank of Bayouf Pout in Thiès for seven and a half years. She wants to bolster her fruit business selling such local fruits as watermelons, mangos, oranges, mandarine oranges, and clementines, according to the season. Her income allows her to improve living conditions for her family. She is requesting a loan that will be reimbursed at the end of 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sales of local fruit

loans.name: Kilimanjaro Group

texts.es:
Nora es la coordinadora de este grupo, ella inicio su negocio de venta de ropa para poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa comenzó con este negocio hace 5 años vendiendo enfrente de su casa y actualmente vende en mercados rodantes cercanos a su casa.

Blanca inicio su negocio para poder ayudar a su esposo a darles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijas y que no les faltara nada. Inicio hace poco mas de 1 años comenzó como snack vendiendo refrescos, frituras y dulces, actualmente surtió su negocio con más cosas de abarrotes, ya que desea tener su tienda mejor establecida en un futuro.

Nely inicio con su negocio ya que necesitaba una actividad que le permitiera atender a sus hijos y a la vez poder obtener un ingreso extra. Comenzó con este negocio hace 2 años vendiendo para otra persona, pero poco a poco hizo sus clientes por lo que decidió vender independientemente y asi obtener mejores ganancias.

Ellas forman el grupo Kilimanjaro y necesitan $1125 que pagaran en 5 meses para poder comprar mercancía para sus negocios y poder así mantenerlos. Ellas confían que con tu apoyo esto será posible.
texts.en:
Nora is the coordinator of this group. She started her business selling clothes to be able to help her husband with the household expenses. She started this business 5 years ago, selling in front of her house, and she currently sells in street markets close to her home.

Blanca started her business to help her husband give their daughters a better quality of life and make sure they were not lacking in anything. She started a little more than 1 year ago, selling snacks like sodas, chips, and candy. She has currently stocked her business more like a general store, since she wants to have a better established store in the future.

Nely started her business because she needed an activity that would allow her to tend to her children and at the same time obtain an extra income. She started with this business 2 years ago, selling for another person, but little by little she got her own customers so she decided to sell independently in order to obtain higher profits.

They form the group Kilimanjaro and they need $1125, which they will pay back in 5 months, to be able to buy merchandise for their businesses and thus be able to maintain them. They trust that with your support this will be possible.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying merchandise

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena is divorced with a daughter. She runs a small business selling groceries at a local market. Yelena has been in this business for 6 years. She is very industrious and a hard worker. Her integrity, determination and perseverance have ensured the sustainability and growth of her business. 

Yelena has gradually been able to save some money and reinvest it in her business. Between these savings and loans from Nadiya Ukraine, she has been able to increase her inventory and sales volume. Presently, she has about $6,000 of working capital. Yelena is requesting a loan for 5000 Grivnas that will allow her to increase her assortment of inventory. She is planning to buy food products wholesale for further retail sales. This loan will help Yelena increase her inventory and cater to an ever-increasing number of customers, further promoting stable expansion for her business.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is a widow with one daughter, Yekaterina. Tatyana's vending stall, where she sells bedding and sheets, is located at one of the busiest city markets, called Kolos. She's been in this business for 2 years. 

Tatyana is a serious and prudent business owner. Her perseverance, together with lending services from Nadiya Ukraine, has enabled her to gradually expand her business. Today Tatyana owns a container-store. Container-stores are large metal shipping containers often used for overseas shipping. They can be used for storage, but make an ideal shelter from which market vendors can sell merchandise. In Nikolaev, most market entrepreneurs own little stores or such containers-stores. Tatyana's working capital has grown to $6,000 now. Tatyana's pleasant manner and willingness to meet clients' needs have helped her keep a loyal clientele. Tatyana is requesting a loan of 2000 Grivnas to purchase an assortment of linen sheets and blankets in bulk to sell during this chilly fall season. Her responsibility, stable business growth, and prompt payment record characterize Tatyana as a consistent and serious entrepreneur capable of loan repayment.  

Note: this is a short-term seasonal loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: To increase assortment of inventory

loans.name: Svitlana

texts.en:
Svitlana S. is a married mom who supports her family with a small business selling women's clothing. She has been in business for 4 years and has gained much experience as an entrepreneur and sales person. One of the things she enjoys the most about her business is the opportunity to help her customers look their best. She tries to have a variety of clothing on hand so that she is able to offer a range of choices and meet each customer's needs.

Financial support from Nadiya Ukraine has been instrumental in the success of Svitlana's business. She has been able to take out several loans and has established herself as one of the best clients with our loan office in Drogobych. Svitlana's goal is to continue to learn and improve her business. She has requested a loan of 3000 Grivnas so that she can purchase some additional inventory. Fall is a very busy season for many market vendors in Ukraine. This loan will enable Svitlana to be prepared for increased demand and earn some additional income that will help her and her family.

Note: this is a short-term seasonal loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock

loans.name: Unidas Para El Progreso Group

texts.en: Leonia B. is part of a larger group of women hoping to start their own businesses. Leonia is a hard working mother of three young children, who is looking to better her future. She plans on starting a small business selling clothes. Her immediate goal is to save money to buy a small vehicle to help her business grow, and her dream is to have her own store someday! On behalf of Leonia, the rest of the group, and Esperanza International--- Thank you for your support!!

loans.use: To start a business

loans.name: Liberacion Group

texts.en: Ana F. is the representative of a group named "Liberacion."  The five people in this group are hoping to receive a loan so that they can each start their own small business and better their lives. Ana is a hard working mother of two children. She is hoping to start a small business selling cookes, candies, and other small goods. Her dream is to increase her business! On behalf of Ana, the group, and Esperanza International-- Thank you for your support!!

loans.use: To set up a food vendor business

loans.name: Taitu

texts.en:
Taitu S. is a 57 year old wife and mother. She has four children, who are all in school. She has been a food vendor for fifteen years. She prepares and sells wakye, which is a local dish prepared from rice and eaten with all kinds of sauces. It is a delicacy that many Ghanaian enjoy everyday as either breakfast, lunch, or dinner.

Her business is doing well and she wants to expand her operations to serve more customers. With this loan, she wants to buy more vegetables, rice, cooking oil, and assorted meat and fish. She hopes this loan would help her increase her savings to improve her family's wellbeing. She would be very grateful for that assistance.

Taitu belongs to a group called Ntoboase Trust Group, meaning patience. The group members assist one another to repay their loans on time.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice, cooking oil, vegetables, meats, and fish.

loans.name: Jehova Es Mi Pastor Group

texts.en: Luciana is the representative of the group "Jehova Es Mi Pastor." This group consists of 10 very ambitious people. Luciana is an extremely determined mother of four young children, all under the age of 11. Luciana is hoping to start a small business selling clothing! She wants to have her own clothing store, and she dreams of having a thriving business so she can better the lives of her children! On behalf of Luciana, the group, and Esperanza International--- We thank you for you support!

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.en: Anastasia E. is 45 years old. She is married and has three children who are currently in school. She is a petty trader who trades in yams. Her husband and children are very proud of her because of the enormous contribution she makes in the home. Selling yams has enabled her to support her family at home for two years now. She wants to use the loan to buy yam tubers to increase her inventory. She believes this loan will help her save for her children's education. She is member of the group called "Ntoboase" Trust Group. Members agree to guarantee the repayment of loans for each.

loans.use: To buys yam tubers.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama P. is a 37-year-old mother of two children who are in school. She is very hard working and resourceful. For two years she has been selling charcoal in her neighborhood. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all traditional Ghanaian homes. Ama obtains charcoal from the villages surrounding of Obuasi, where she lives, and she retails the charcoal to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of charcoal to increase her inventory. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase her savings so she can pay her children's educational fees. She belongs to the community group called Ntoboase Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of loans for one another.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of charcoal.

loans.name: La Puerta De La Esperanza Group

texts.en: Alba G. is the representative of this group of five named "La Puerta D. La Esperanza." This is a group of women who want to improve their lives, and all want to start their own small business. Alba is a dedicated mother of four older children, and has many hopes and dreams. One of Alba's dreams is to do well enough in her business to remodel her house. She plans to start a small business selling various small items, and hopes to have her very own store someday. On behalf of Alba, the group, and Esperanza International--- Thank you for your support!!!

loans.use: Vendor of small crafts

loans.name: Safura

texts.en:
Safura S. is 30 years old. She is a married woman with three children. Her kids are in school. Safura is resourceful and enterprising. She operates a local restaurant and sells local foods like kenkey and other local dishes. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup.

Safura has a strategic business location, giving her favorable business sales. She needs the loan to enable her to inject additional capital into the business to scale up production and increase her income level. With the loan, she wants to purchase more raw materials like maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood to facilitate her food production.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials like maize, cassava, plantains, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys N. is 45 years old. She is widowed and the mother of three children who are currently in school. She has manufacturered palm kernel oil for four years. Palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernel. The palm kernel is a by-product of palm oil. The palm kernel is also processed through various stages to obtain the palm kernel oil which is used to prepare many local dishes. Her production is on a small scale because she lacks the working capital to buy a machine to process the palm kernel oil. She wants to use the loan to buy more palm kernel and an electric milling machine to increase her efficiency so she can produce oil in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business snd raise more income to support the business and to provide food for her family and finance her children's education. She belongs to the community group called Ntoboase (Patience) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of loans for one another.

loans.use: To buy palm kernel and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Unidos Venceremos Group

texts.en:
Arturo is the representative of the group known as Unidos Venceremos, which consists of 10 hard working and ambitious people looking to start small businesses. Arturo, the father of two young children, is hoping to better not only his life but also the lives of his children by starting a small clothing sale business. His ultimate goal is to become a big clothing distributor, and his dream is to own his own house someday! 

On behalf of Arturo, the group, and Esperanza International--- Thank you for your support!!!

loans.use: To become a clothing vendor

loans.name: Jerisa

texts.en: Jerisa I. is 35 years old. She is married and has four children. She sells porridge and lingerie in her neighborhood. Porridge is one of the local foods that is popular for breakfast. It is prepared from boiled milled maize or millet grains, and is eaten with sugar, milk, and bread. Because she has a large customer base, she wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, millet, sugar, and milk to increase her production. She also wants to upgrade her lingerie sales. She hopes to make a good income to support her children in school. She is a member of group called Judah Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of loans for one another.

loans.use: To buy maize, millet, sugar, milk, and lingerie

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
El Sr. Francisco C. está tramitando una casa por medio de Infonavit pero le esta haciendo falta una diferencia de monto para el enganche.

El nos comento que desea empezar un patrimonio para su familia, ya que tiene barios años pagando renta de casa y pues prefiere pagar su propia vivienda..

Sr. Francisco trabaja en una empresa como ejecutivo de cobranza esté es su ingreso familiar. Al paso de los años que ha estado trabajando el a horrado por medio de Infonavit para una vivienda pero le está haciendo falta una diferencia de $575.00 dlls. Para que le puedan entregar su casa es por eso que el nos solicita un préstamo para pagarle a Infonavit.
texts.en:
Francisco C. is in the process of purchasing a home through Infonavit but he is missing a part of the down payment.

He was saying that he wishes to start a legacy for his family. After having paid rent for so many years he would prefer to have his own house.

Fracisco works in a company as a financial executive and this is the family income. Through the passing years that he has worked he has been able to save through Infonavit for a home but he is still missing $575 US. He is requesting this loan so that he can pay this last amount to Infonavit so that they will finally give him his house.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To cover the remaining portion of the down payment for a house.

loans.name: 21 De Agosto Group

texts.en:
The "21 de agosto" (August 21st) group is made up of ten women and four men who live in the tropical Santa C. region of eastern Bolivia. Many of the group members sell cosmetics and clothing. Others have different businesses at the La Ramada, Abasto and Mutualista Markets, like CD sales, carpentry, and candy sales. Some sell ducks and eggs, while others sell electronic games. One woman has a hair salon, and one man works as a salaried driver. Their clientele is the general public, for the most part. The group members say they plan to use this loan to buy more merchandise for their respective businesses and to buy more tools to work with.

Most of the group members have one to five years of experience in their respective lines of work, though three of the group members have more than ten years of experience.

Though most of the group members have previous credit experience at other Bolivian microfinance organizations, this is their first loan as a group from AgroCapital.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell or more tools to work with

loans.name: Las Puntuales Group

texts.en:
The Las Puntuales (Punctual Women) group is maD. up of 11 women and 2 men who live in the tropical Santa Cruz region of eastern Bolivia. All of the group members live in the same neighborhood and know each another well; they are committed to guaranteeing one another's loans and to making their repayments on time.

Each of the group members has his or her own business: some sell clothing, cosmetics, party favors, appliances, beef, and coca leaves; others are tailors and seamstresses. Most have between one and five years of experience in their respective businesses, though Rosmery has been selling party supplies for 40 years!

Most of the group plans to use their Kiva loan to buy more merchandise to sell. Most group members have previous experience with group loans at other Bolivian microfinance institutions.

loans.use: Buy bulk merchandise to sell

loans.name: Las Autenticas Group

texts.en:
The Las Autenticas (The Authentic Women) is a group of 12 people, nine of whom are women and three are men. The group members are from the Elizardo Pérez area and are involved in a variety of economic activities.

Mr. Elio Juanito Gutiérrez López is the group president and works as a tailor. The treasurer, Mrs. Julia Andrea H. Limache, has two children and works as an assistant on the minibus that she owns (minibuses are the primary form of public transportation in La Paz and El Alto). The secretary, Miss Maria Luisa J. D. Y., sells food at different markets.

These ladies and gentlemen are new to AgroCapital. They did not know anything about the institution, much less about communal banking, but now that they have formed their group and received their loan,* they are ready to work together responsibly in unity and solidarity so that they can continue on to their second loan cycle and take out a bit more money. * Note that loans you see fundraising on Kiva have actually already been disbursed; this is so that clients don't have to sit around and wait for their loan to be funded on Kiva in order to invest in their businesses. Kiva's partner MFIs are repaid by Kiva at the end of each month.

Translated and elaborated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Grupo conformado por 12 personas D. los cuales 9 son mujeres y 3 varones. El nombre del grupo es Las Autenticas, las señoras son D. la zona Elizardo Pérez el grupo se dedican en diferentes actividades. La sr. Elio Juanito Gutiérrez López es el presidenta del grupo es empleado en costura; La tesorera Sra. Julia Andrea H. L., tiene dos hijos, ella es ayudante D. minibús que es propio. La secretaria Srta. Maria Luisa J. D. Y., ella venD. comida en diferentes ferias Las señoras y señores son nuevas en Agrocapital ellos no sabían nada sobre la institución y mucho menos que existía la banca comunal, pero ahora que ya conformaron su grupo y se les otorgo el crédito, ellas están ahora con muchas ganas D. trabajar juntas, unidas y sobre todo ser solidarias y responsables, para así poder pasar al segundo ciclo y sacar un poco más D. crédito.

loans.use: Buy bulk merchandise to sell

loans.name: Sarantañani Dos Group

texts.en:
The Sarantañani Dos group is maD. up of fifteen people, including some members who just joined during this loan cycle. All the group members are from the same neighborhood, Alto Lima, in the city of El Alto. The group president is Mr Vicente Antonio E. Choquetanga.

The group members are involved in a variety of economic activities. All work as vendors, selling skirts, shawls, plastics, cleaning supplies, paints, clothing, weavings, CDs, glasses, toys, sweets and cell phone accessories. Most have one to five years of experience in their respective businesses, though four of the group members have ten or 15 years of experience. Most of the group plans to use their Kiva loan to buy more merchandise to sell.

The group is currently in its third loan cycle, and expects all of its members will behave well and make all of their repayments on time, in a normal fashion. Their loan officer will work with them constantly, especially on repayment days and during group meetings.

Translated and elaborated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

GRUPO SARNATAÑANI DOS este grupo está conformado en base grupo antiguo y nuevas, son D. la misma zona Alto Lima, a cuya cabeza está el Sr. Vicente Antonio E. Choquetanga, como Presidente del grupo, están ya en 3er. Ciclo, se espera que el comportamiento sea buena, en sus amortizaciones o pagos normales en las reuniones programadas, los miembros del grupo tienen diferentes actividades, el seguimiento se hará constante especialmente en las fechas D. pago y reuniones.

loans.use: To buy bulk merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Trebol Group

texts.en:
The Trebol (Clover) Communal Bank is maD. up of 12 members, mostly women, who live in Viacha (outsiD. of El Alto) near Ejercito Ave and Murillo St. The group is led by its president, secretary, and treasurer: Mrs. Petrona T. C., Lucy L. M., and Rossio A. Limache. The group members are involved in a variety of different businesses: some sell sweets, fruits, vegetables, cosmetics, clothing, shoes, books, envelopes, toys, and gifts; others repair cars or work in construction. About half of the group has between four and seven years of experience working in their respective businesses, while the other half has between 10 and 37 years of experience.

The group finished its second loan cycle with a reputation for punctuality and discipline. It is a group of very united, responsible people, but unfortunately, due to the current situation in Bolivia, many of its former members were forced to leave the country. As a result, Trebol is launching its third loan cycle with some new members. The group is certain that the loan they will receive will allow them to improve and expand their businesses.

Translated and elaborated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

El Banco Comunal denominado TREBOL, esta conformado por señoras que en su mayoría radican en VIACHA por inmediaciones del la Av. del Ejercito, C. Murillo y otras circundantes. La mesa directiva esta conformada por la Sra. Petrona T. C., Lucy L. M. y Rossio A. Limache, las personas componentes D. este grupo se dedican principalmente a la comercialización D. dulces, frutas, verduras y otros. Este grupo culmino su segundo ciclo caracterizándose por su puntualidad y disciplina, son un grupo D. personas muy unidas y responsables, sin embargo debido a la situación coyuntural del país muchas personas se ven obligadas a abandonan el País y también los grupos, en consecuencia están emprendiendo su tercer ciclo con gente nueva y están muy seguras D. que el crédito que les ofrece la institución les facilitara el mejoramiento y crecimiento D. sus negocios.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to sell

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.en:
The Nuevo Amanecer C (New Dawn C) Group is made up of eleven women and one man who live in the Ciudad Satélite neighborhood, near Cotel Plaza and Cívica Ave in the city of El Alto, Bolivia.

The group is led by its president, secretary and treasurer: Rosa Marlene Unzueta, Nelson Corrales Soliz and Maria Teresa T. G.. The people that make up this group are involved in a variety of different businesses, including selling jewelry, deodorant, clothing, cosmetics, meat, appliances and fruit. Others work as secretaries, graphic designers, and beauty salon attendants. About half of the group has between one and three years of experience in their respective businesses, while the rest of the group has 10 to 20 years of experience (except for Gloria, who has been selling clothing for 35 years!).

This group completed its second loan cycle without any problems, so they were able to continue onto their third cycle. The group's makeup is a little bit different in this cycle, since some people had to leave the group because they were traveling. Still, the prospects for the new members look good; they are a very humble and responsible group of people. The group is certain that the loan they will receive from our institution will allow them to improve and expand their businesses.

Translated and elaborated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

El Banco Comunal denominado NUEVO AMANECER C, esta conformado por señoras que en su mayoría radican en la Ciudad Satelite por inmediaciones de la Plaza COTEL y la Av. Cívica de la Ciudad de El Alto. La mesa directiva esta conformada por la Sra. Rosa Marlene Unzueta, Nelson Corrales Soliz y Maria Teresa T.; las personas que componen este grupo se dedican principalmente a la comercialización de joyas, desodorantes, ropa, frutas y otros. Este grupo culmino su segundo ciclo sin ningún problema, motivo por el cual se le otorgara el tercer ciclo, se reorganizo debido a que algunas personas ya no participaran por motivo de viaje sin embargo se tiene buenas perspectivas de las socias nuevas, ellas son un grupo de personas muy humildes y responsables; están muy seguras de que el crédito que les ofrece la institución les facilitara el mejoramiento y crecimiento de sus negocios.

loans.use: To buy bulk merchandise to resell.

loans.name: Gran Poder Group

texts.en:
The Gran Poder (Great Power) group is maD. up of 16 women and three men who live in Sucre, Bolivia. Most of the group members are mothers and have children who are five or older. The group members each have their own businesses: some sell cosmetics, clothing, cold cuts, or cell phones; others work as seamstresses, drivers, and cooks. Most of the group members have between one and five years of experience in their respective businesses. Aleida and Porfiria each have 10 years of experience (Porfiria owns a bus, and Aleida repairs cell phones).

The group members will use their loans to buy more merchandise to sell or materials to produce their various products. The group does not have any previous credit history, either with AgroCapital or at other financial institutions. Their loan officer describes the group as very enterprising and experienced.

loans.use: Buy merchandise or materials for business

loans.name: Las Legionarias Group

texts.en:
The Las Legionarias (The Legionnaires) group consists of 13 women and one man who live in the tropical Santa C. region of eastern Bolivia. The group members all know one another from their neighborhood. None of them are related, though they do share similar last names, like many Bolivians.

Each of the group members has his or her own business: some sell clothing, cosmetic products, food, white majao (a traditional dish from eastern Bolivia maD. with jerky, sausage, bananas, tomatoes, rice and yucca), and medications; others work as radio taxi drivers, manicurists, or cell phone company reps; and some do filming and proviD. amplification services. Most have between one and five years of experience in their respective businesses, though some have as many as 15, and Teofilo has 20 years of experience as a musician! The group members say they will use this loan to buy more raw ingredients with which to make their products or to buy tools or equipment to use in their businesses.

Most of the group has previous experience with group loans at other Bolivian microfinance institutions. They have promised to make all of their payments on time, as scheduled.

loans.use: Buy raw ingredients/materials to make various products

loans.name: Feliciano

texts.es: Don Feliciano es un hombre soltero de 52 años de edad, habita en el barrio Laureles Norte y se desempeña como conductor. Tiene dos hijos de 17 y 20 años de edad, los cuales ya son independientes a él, ellos ya formaron sus propias familia. Don Feliciano tiene 10 años de ejercer la labor de conductor. Trabajo que ha desempeñado con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación, porque su meta en la vida era preparar a sus hijos, pero debido a la difícil situación sus hijos tuvieron que irse a otro país. El motivo del crédito es la mejora en la infraestructura de su vivienda, construirá una pared de división en su casa, ya que Don Feliciano quiere que la casa esté terminada para cuando sus hijos regresen al país.
texts.en:
Don Feliciano is 52 years old and single. He lives in the Laureles Norte neighborhood and works as a driver. He has two sons who are 17 and 20 years old. His children are independent and each have their own families. Don Feliciano has been working as a driver for ten years. He is very hard-working and dedicated to his job, since his goal in life was to raise his children well, but due to tough circumstances his children had to leave the country. Don Feliciano is requesting this loan to make home improvements. He will build a dividing wall, because he wants the house to be ready when his sons return to the country.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a dividing wall in his home

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.en:
The Renacer ("Rebirth") group is maD. up of eleven women and two men who know one another from their neighborhood in the tropical Santa Cruz region of eastern Bolivia. The two men in the group, Oscar and Ignacio, are brothers, and Elvira and Erika are sisters.

Each of the group members has their own business: some sell clothing, shoes, handicrafts, dry goods, baked goods, and cosmetics; others work as tailors, make hammocks or run lunch counters. All of the group members have one to five years of experience in their respective businesses, except for Doña Candelaria Maria, who has been running her lunch counter for twenty years!

The group members say they will use this loan to buy more ingredients to make their products or tools for their businesses. Most of the group members have had previous experience with group loans at other Bolivian microfinance institutions. They all promise to make their repayments on time.

loans.use: Buy more materials to make products and tools for businesses

loans.name: Luis Enrique

texts.es: Don Luis Enrique Sequeiro es un pequeño comerciante del Mercado Oriental de Managua. Tiene 51 años de edad, habita en el barrio Rubén Darío, es soltero, tiene dos hijos de 32 y 23 años de edad quienes le ayudan con el negocio. Tiene un tramo en este mercado, en donde vende cosméticos, hace algunos meses el mercado sufrió un fuerte incendio que acabó con gran parte de los tramos, y entre éstos tramos afectados ésta la del señor Luis Enrique Sequeiro quién perdió casi la totalidad de su mercancía. Está haciendo mucho esfuerzo por volver a levantarse, es por eso que solicita el préstamo para compra de nueva mercadería y así poder empezar a formar su inventario nuevamente.
texts.en:
Luis Enrique Sequeiro is a small vendor from the Oriental Market of Managua. He is 51, lives in the Ruben Dario neighbourhood, single, has two children ages 32 and 23 who help in the business. He has a section in the market, where he sells cosmetics. Months ago the market suffered a strong fire that destroyed large part of the sections, including Mr. Sequeiro’s, who lost most of his merchandise. He is working hard to get his business up again, reason why he requests a loan to purchase merchandise and build his new inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Renew Inventory

loans.name: Jose Maria

texts.es: El señor José Maria T. Caníz de 65 años de edad, Casado,  actualmente reside en Paraje Paquemoyop, Cantón Chuisuc, de Totonicapán. Hace más de treinta y un años  (31) años viene trabajando de comerciante y elaborando rebozos típicos con variedad de estilos y diseños. Entregando su producción en Antigua Guatemala y los días de plaza de nuestra ciudad realiza sus ventas y el  se acercó a las oficinas de Asdir para solicitar un crédito para invertit mas en su negocio   para ampliar su capital de trabajo y mejorar su producción, ya que los rebozos es una prenda que las mujeres de nuestro pueblo les distingue también los turistas que visitan nuestro país les llama la atención por sus colores combinados y el acabado de la prenda y es por esta misma razón don José María  para surtir su mercaderia  y con ello le permite creser  y desarrollar economicamente que un ejemplo para sus nietos con la edad que tiene sigue trabajando nos cuenta que esa actividad lo ha heredado de su querido padre y es la especialidad de esa comunidad las artesanias.
texts.en:
Señor José Maria T. Caníz is 65 years old. He is married and currently lives in Paraje Paquemoyop, Cantón Chuisuc, Totonicapán. He has been in business for thirty-one years, making shawls in various styles and designs typical of the region. He sells the shawls in Antigua Guatemala on market days. He has been to the Asdir office to ask for a loan so he could invest more money in his business, increase his capital, and expand production. Because the shawls are garments that give the women of our town a distinct appearance, tourists who visit our country are attracted to them for their coordinating colours and their quality finish. For this reason José María wishes to increase his stock so that his business can grow and develop. It will be an example for his grandchildren who are at an age to begin work. He tells us that he inherited his business from his beloved father, and it is a speciality among the artisan community.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase his stock

loans.name: Soledad Regina

texts.es: El señora Soledad Regina P. P. de 39 años de edad, Casada, con tres hijos  actualmente reside en Paraje Tzan Sajoc, Cantón Pasajoc, Totonicapán. Hace ya varios años que viene trabajando comerciante y elaborando chumpas, güipiles y otras prendas típicas con variedad de estilos y diseños. Entregando su producción en Chichicastenango, Quiche, Solóla y Salcaja Quetzaltenango   y   hace unos  años se acercó a las oficinas de Asdir para solicitar un crédito  para ampliar  su negocio todo fue un exito nuevamente solicita un credito vara seguir variando su producto  ya que se acercan las fiestas de  la feria titular de nuestro pueblo para que el pueda producir más y así obtener buenas ganancias  para el beneficio del mismo. Ya que también se acerca el fin de año y así con el crédito solicitado pueda exponer su trabajo a los turistas que visitan nuestro país y así ellos puedan ser acreedores de esta producción tan tradicional de nuestro país.
texts.en:
Mrs. Soledad Regina P. P. is 39 years old, married, and with three children. She currently lives in Paraje Tzan Sajoc, Cantón Pasajoc, Totonicapán. It has been several years since she started working as a shopkeeper making jackets, blouses of bright colors and indigenous designs, and a variety of other typical. She distributes her products to Chichicastenango, Quiche, Solóla and Salcaja Quetzaltenango. After several years she approached the Asdir offices to ask for a loan in order to increase the size of her business. It was a total success. Now she is looking for a new loan in order to diversify her products before her town’s main festival. The purpose of this is to increase productivity and increase profits. The end of the year is also approaching and with this loan she can expand her business to the tourists that visit her country, giving them the chance they deserve to buy her country’s traditional products.

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials and accesories

loans.name: Manuela Transito

texts.es: La señora Manuela Transito S. C. es originaria del municipio de Totonicapan  pueblo del occidente de la capital de Guatemala, dona Manuela solicita un credito en las oficinas de asdir para mejora su calidad de vida y la de su familia, atraves de ampliar su cobertura de mecardo actualmente vende en los mercados de Chichicastenango, Panajachel  con variedad de telas tipicas con el credito desea agregar otro pito de tejido de Güipiles del departamento de Totonicapan  ya que es el traje del departamento de Totonicapan.  Asi mismo ya se esta finalizando el ciclo escolar  y endonde varios jovenes quieren aprender este arte y doña manuela se caracteriza a ensenarles a los jovenes.
texts.en:
Manuel Transito S. C. is a native of the municipality of Totonicapan, a town located west of the capital of Guatamela. Dona Manuela is asking for a loan from ASDIR to improve her family´s quality of life, by broadening her offering in the market. She currently sells a variety of traditional fabrics in the Chichicastenango and Panajachel markets. With this loan she would like to add other fabrics like Güipiles (or huipiles, a Mayan textile made into a tunic or blouse) from Totonicapan, which is the traditional outfit from the department of Totonicapan. At the same time, since the school year is drawing to an end and many young poeple want to learn this art, Doña Manuela would like to teach them.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Carlos Manuel

texts.es: El señor Carlos Manuel P. R. de 30 años de edad, Casado, actualmente reside en la 1ra. Avenida 4 Calle 01-37 Zona 4, de Totonicapán. Hace más de ocho (8) años viene trabajando de artesano en la elaboración de bolsas, mochilas, billeteras y chalecos con tela típica,   con la variedad de estilos y diseños. Entregando su producción en Panajachel y el  se acercó a las oficinas de Asdir para solicitar un crédito para por surtir mas su mercaderia  en donde el dicho crédito será invertido para ampliar su capital de trabajo y mejorar su producción, ya que los bolsas típicas,  también los turistas que visitan nuestro país les llama la atención por sus colores combinados y el acabado de las prenda y es por esta misma razón don Carlos Manuel  realiza su préstamo para ampliar su capital generar mas productos con la idea de visitar otros pueblos para poner al servicio de ellos el trabajo  de Totonicapán
texts.en:
Mr. Carlos Manuel P. R. is 30 years old, married, and currently lives in the 1st Ave. 4 Street 01-27 Zone 4, of Totonicapan. For more than 8 years now he has been working as an artisan creating bags, backpacks, wallets, and vests with cloth typical of the region, in a variety of styles and designs. As he delivered his products at Panajachel, he came to the offices of Asdir to request a loan to be able to stock more merchandise, in which that loan will be invested to expand his working capital and improve his production, given that these typical bags get the attention of tourists who visit our country because of the combined colors of the cloth and the high quality finishes of the garments. This is precisely the reason that don Carlos Manuel requests a loan to expand his capital and generate more products, with the idea of visiting other towns and offer to the the work from Totonicapan.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying materials for embroidered products.

loans.name: Padre San Jacinto Group

texts.es:
La comunidad D. Acostambo pertenece al Distrito D. Acostambo, Provincia D. Tayacaja ubicado en el Departamento: Huancavelica El distrito D. Acostambo se localiza a los 3,600 m.s.n.m, se encuentra ubicado al noreste D. Huancavelica, al final del inmenso Valle del Mantaro y muy cerca a la quebrada D. Huanta ayacucho, se tiene referencias por los historiadores D. la zona, D. que el Inca en nuestros antepasados cuando avanzaba con su tropa, por los caminos D. entonces, desD. el Cuzco hacia Quito, pasando necesariamente por este territorio, acampaba con sus tropas en el lugar hoy conocido como "TAMBO MACHAY" (lugar turístico D. Acostambo), el cual está constituido por una secuencia D. cuevas geológicas que cuentan con ambientes claramente delimitados.

Actividades Principales: Agricultura, ganadería, Acuicultura, Comercio, Artesanía y turismo

R. V., es viudo, se dedica a la compra D. vacas y toros. Rómulo es padre y madre D. sus hijos, su esposa falleció en un accidente, él lucha para que sus hijos sean profesionales.

Isabel U., es casada y se dedica al negocio D. compra D. cerdos, con el préstamo que recibirá comprará pequeños cerditos para engordar y vender en chicharronerías D. Izcuchaca.

Rosa T., es casada y su negocio es dar pensión a profesores D. la escuela, invertirá su préstamo en comprar arroz y azúcar por sacos para su negocio, Le gustaría tener su propia bodeguita bien surtida con golosinas y mas adelante tener su propio restaurante.
texts.en:
The Acostambo community is in the Acostambo Distrit of the Tayacaja Province, Huancavelica Department. The Acostambo District is 3,600 meters above sea level and is situated to the northeast of Huancavelica, at the end of the immense Mantaro Valley. It is very close to the Huanta riverbed, which is important to local historians because the Incan troops, advancing along the road from Cuzco to Quito, necessarily passed through this territory. The troops camped in the area which today is known as “Tambo Machay” (a tourist destination in Acostambo), which is maD. up of a series of well-defined geological caves. Main activities: Agriculture, stockbreeding, aquaculture, commerce, handicrafts, and tourism R. V. is a widower who purchases cows and bulls for a living. He has been both a father and mother to his children since his wife died in an accident. He has fought to turn his children into professionals. Isabel U. is married and dedicates herself to the business of purchasing pigs. With the loan she will receive, she will purchase piglets to fatten up and sell to pork rinds vendors in Izcuchaca. Rosa T. is married and her business is to proviD. board to schoolteachers. She will use her loan to purchase rice and sugar sacks for her business. She would like to have her own small shop well supplied with sweets, and to own her own restaurant later on.

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The l Padre San Jacinto community bank requests a loan of s/5200 to be used by its 11 members to  implement their businesses.

loans.name: Mr. Seing He Village Bank Group

texts.en: TH. village bank, located in Trapeang Srang Village in tH. Takeo Province, consists of ten people who each plan to use tH. loan for different purposes. Mr. Sieng H. is tH. village bank president who was elected by its members. H. sells lottery tickets and makes less than $2 a day, a low income to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Mork Srey Touch, owns a small grocery store in tH. local market. Since her business is going well, sH. wants to expand it. So, her husband, Mr. Sieng H., decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery product for her inventory. Mrs. Sieng H. is 44 years old and tH. mother of five children three of whom are attending tH. local school and two of whom are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more grocery product for his inventory.

loans.name: Mrs. Loem Sao Group

texts.en:
Loem S. is 38 years old, married, and has five children. Four are enrolled in the local school, while the other is too young to attend. Loem is working hard to provide her children with a quality education and support her family financially.

Loem S. is the group leader of a business located in Ou Kralanh Duol Village in the Takeo Province. Her group consists of six members. She owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice to make a living. Currently, she faces several problems, including infertile ground which is affecting her crop. In order to solve this problem, Loem has decided to ask for a loan in order to purchase fertilizers and enrich her land. Her husband, Mr. Un Moeurn, is a livestock breeder and currently has two cows and two pigs.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's developing entrepreneurs. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Mrs. Nut Sarem Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eleven people in Pou Roung Village in Takeo Province are asking for a loan that they will each use differently. Mrs. Nut S. is a livestock breeder who raises two cows and two pigs. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets for breeding. Mrs. Nut S. is a 46-year-old widow with three children. Two are employed in a garment factoR. and the other is attending the local school. All eleven are members of AMK, a local bank. AMK members have a reliable record on repaying loans. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has never defaulted on a KIVA loan.

loans.use: buying pigs

loans.name: Mrs. Ney Pov Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, which consists of twelve people, is located in Ta Sman Village in Takeo Province and Mrs. Ney P. is the elected village bank president. She makes her living by growing rice. Mrs. Ney P.'s current problem is that her soil is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Ney P. has decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizers to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Hang Phat, cuts bamboo and sells it at the market. He makes about $1.50 a day. Mrs. Ney P. is 49 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory and the remaining two attend the local school.

All the members of this village loan have end-of-term loans and they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main policy because they are the most beneficial type of loan for Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Mrs. Un Hoen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people from the Ta Sman Village in Takeo Province would like a loan that they each plan to use in a different way. Mrs. Un H. is the village bank president. She is a farmer and owns one hector which she uses to grow rice. Her plantation faces a problem because her field is infertile so she is unable to produce her crop. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Un H. would like a loan to buy fertilizers that would help her field and in turn help her produce a better crop. Her husband, Mr. Chea Noy, is a laborer who cuts down and sells bamboo. Mrs. Un H. is 40 years old and a mother of four children, one of whom is a construction worker while the others attend the local school. 

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Fifteen members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support her field to produce a better crop.

loans.name: Mr. Seik Khorn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Seik K. is the president of The Village Bank in Hang Heng Village, Takeo Province.  He is a farmer who owns a small plot of land and he cultivates rice. Throughout the plantation the soil has become infertile which effects the production of his crops.   In order to solve this problem Mr. K. would like to take out a loan to purchase fertilizers to better his field and purchase pesticides to kill unwanted insects.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Eight members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term.
