Josephine is now looking for a loan to buy more food items for the expansion of her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Chausiku, who has a business dealing with firewood sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for the expansion of her business

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma, 24 and married, has been a chicken seller since 2003. She works long hours everyday at her business.

Fatma previously took out a successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She is now seeking a loan to buy more chickens for resale.

loans.use: To buy more chicken for resale.

loans.name: Ayesha's Group

texts.en:
Ayesha baji is the wife of A. M. and lives in an area named Walton, in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the last 25 years. She is the mother of four children: two boys and two girls. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.

Ayesha baji's husband is a milk seller by trade with an experience of 15 years. Ayesha baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She has successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy a buffalo to expand her husband's milk business.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy leather to make more shoes to sell. Martha baji wants a loan to buy tools for repairing bicycles.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo for her family's milk business

loans.name: Mkufu's Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en:
Mkufu, 49, is a widow with five children. She has sold juice and handbags since 2004. Every day, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

In the past, Mkufu has taken out a successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Mkufu is now looking for a another loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Miraji, who also sells snacks.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Razi

texts.en: Razi is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory and has  settled in the Finnish houses, which are built temporarily on the front line in the Fuzuli region.  He was born in 1948. This man is married, has 3 children. He has been in this business for 5 years. Now he needs a loan of US$ 750 to buy foodstuffs for improving his business.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs for re-sale

loans.name: Bashiran's Group

texts.en:
Bashiran baji is a wife of S. M.. She lives in an area named Walton, in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 28 years. She is the mother of one son, Javed. Javed is married and has one son. Bashiran baji's husband has a food business. He has been in this business for the last 10 years. He makes Punjab food (chicken biryani particularly). Bashiran baji sells rice. She buys rice from different shops and sells it in her community. She successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy material (spices, cooking oil) to expand to her husband's food business.

Other members of Bashiran baji’s loan group include: Naseem baji, who wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a three-wheeled motor vehicle). Mussarat baji, who wants a loan to buy vegetables to resell. Shamim baji, who wants a loan to buy shoes to resell. Nasreen baji, who wants a loan to buy material decoration pieces (colored lights, flower pots) for her decor business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible for repaying the loan.

loans.use: To buy material for her food business

loans.name: Sikuzani's Tuamke Group

texts.en:
Sikuzani is 25 years old and married with two children who are five and three. She has been a bites (chapati) and clothing seller since 2005. She works every day from 6 am to 5 pm at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $185 from her sales.

Sikuzani is looking for a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling porridge, dreads, charcoal, fish, perfumes, and clothing.

loans.use: To expand her business selling clothing and bites.

loans.name: Frida's Tuamke Group

texts.en:
Frida is 29 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 9, 8 and 6 years old. She has been a bites and fish seller since June 2008. Every day, she works from 4am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Frida is now looking for a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with shop ownership, charcoal sales, phone vouchers, and food sales.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 34 years old. She is married with 5 children aged between 18 and 4 years old. She has been a tailoring, soap and firewood seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

In the past, Amina has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Amina is now looking for a loan to add items to her current stock.

loans.use: To add items to her current stock

loans.name: Halima's Tuamke Group

texts.en:
Halima is 20 years old and she is single. She has been a bites seller since 2001. Every day, she works from 10am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Halima is now requesting a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with charcoal sales, coconut and fish sales, fish, juice and clothes sales.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Azim

texts.en:
Azim, who was born in 1965, is married and has 3 children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. He has settled in the Fizuli region of the village of Bala Bahmanli.

Azim has been in tombstone-making business for 5 years. To improve his business, he needs a loan of $1200 to buy the necessary materials for making tombstones.

loans.use: To buy materials for making tombstones

loans.name: Masheli's Tuamkeni Group

texts.en:
Masheli, 43, is married and has six children between the ages of 4 and 15. She sells fish and bites (snacks). Every day, she works from 6am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $280 from her sales.

Masheli needs a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mtumwa, who sells firewood and fish.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Eldar

texts.en: Eldar is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory, Fuzuli, and now lives in temporary housing which is built on the front line of the Fuzuli region. Eldar was born in 1963, and is married with 4 children. He has been in the business of selling produce for six years, and now he needs a loan to buy agricultural produce and improve his business.

loans.use: To buy more agricultural produce

loans.name: Nuriyya

texts.en:
Nuriyya, who was born in 1981, is a mother of one child. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan in the town of Fizuli; she is now settled in the village of Bala Bahmanli.

Nuriyya and her husband (who is shown in the picture) have been in the business of breeding sheep for 10 years. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy 2 calves.

loans.use: To buy 2 calves

loans.name: Sakhavat

texts.en: Sakhavat was born in 1984. This man is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan in Fuzuli town, settled in Alkhanli village. He has been in this business for 3 years. This young man is single. Now he needs a loan of US$ 1200 to buy the agricultural produce to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy agricultural produce for re-sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase more goods to restock her small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase new fashionable clothing for her small business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Tp purchase supplies to keep selling fried food.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Kohsiwo

texts.en: Kohsiwo A. sells gari which she makes from cassava. She sells it at Duakro near Elmina. Kohsiwo has received no formal education.  She is married and has two children. Her husband is a fisherman. Kohsiwo has been selling gari since 2000. She is responsible for helping her husband pay for the children's school fees and other utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more cassava so she can produce more gari. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: To buy more cassava

loans.name: Charity Yahoo

texts.en: Charity Yahoo A. is a single parent who has six children. She has never received any formal education in her life. Charity Yahoo sells fish which she buys from the fishermen, brings home for processing and preserving, and then sends to the market in Kumasi. She has been in this business since 1998. Charity Yahoo uses her income to pay for the children's school fees and other utility bills. She will use the loan to increase her capital to buy more fish to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to continue building a house for her children.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina A. is married and has 3 children. She has received schooling through Junior High level. Angelina sells "gari" which she uses cassava to produce at Duakro near Elmina, which she has done since 1994.

Angelina uses her income to pay for children's clothing, books, and school fees. Angelina will use the loan to purchase more cassava which is the raw material for processing the gari. With the new profits from her expanded business, Angelina plans to reinvest into her business to increase production and sales which will eventually increase her income.

loans.use: to purchase more cassava which is the raw material for processing "gari"

loans.name: Ami

texts.en:
Ami A. manufactures palm oil and also sells firewood which is the major source of fuel for the fishmongers at Duakro near Elmina. Ami has received no formal education. She is married and has 5 children. Her husband is a security guard.

Ami has been selling firewood since 2004. She is responsible for helping her husband pay the children's school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more palm fruit for the oil production and firewood for re-sale to meet the increase in demand by her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: to buy more palm fruit for the oil production and firewood for re-sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. sells oil and gari at Duakro near Elmina. Mary has a Junior High level education. She is married and has two children. Mary has been selling oil and gari since 1999. She is responsible for feeding her family and paying the utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more coconut oil and gari. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: To buy coconut oil and gari

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria A. is married and has 2 children. She has received schooling through the Junior High level. Starting this year, Victoria has been in the business of selling "gari" (a popular food made from cassava) at Duakro near Elmina. With the income she generates from this business, Victoria is able to pay for her children's school fees and other utility bills.

Victoria is now seeking a loan in order to purchase more cassava to, in turn, make even more gari for her customers. With the expected increase in profits from such an expanded business, Victoria plans to save money to build a house for her children.

loans.use: To improve and expand her gari-making business by purchasing additional cassava (the raw material needed to produce gari)

loans.name: Iren

texts.en:
Iren K. is single and has no children. She has received schooling through Junior High level. Iren sells plastic bowls and also owns a grocery store at Elmina, which she has done since 2005.

Iren uses her income to pay utility bills. Iren will use the loan to purchase footwear which is highly demanded in her area of business and groceries and plastics. With the new profits from her expanded business, Iren plans to complete her building.

loans.use: to purchase footwear and groceries and plastics

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Since 1994, Monica B. has been selling a local meal popularly known as 'Kenkey' which is made from corn. It is one of the most commonly eaten foods in the country at Brenya near Elmina. Monica has received no formal education.  She is married and has six children. Her husband is a teacher. Monica is responsible for feeding the family and for paying the utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more bags of corn, fresh fish which she will fry and sell, and other ingredients that are needed in preparation of the food. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to invest into her children's education.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for the foods she sells
